Review MXenes: Versatile 2D materials with tailored surface chemistry and diverse applications Sunil Kumar a ⁎ Nitu Kumari b Yongho Seo a ⁎ a Department of Nanotechnology and Advanced Materials Engineering and HMC, Sejong University, Seoul 05006, South Korea Department of Nanotechnology and Advanced Materials Engineering and HMC Sejong University Seoul 05006 South Korea Department of Nanotechnology and Advanced Materials Engineering and HMC, Sejong University, Seoul 05006, South Korea b School of Studies in Chemistry, Jiwaji University, Gwalior 474011, India School of Studies in Chemistry Jiwaji University Gwalior 474011 India School of Studies in Chemistry, Jiwaji University, Gwalior 474011, India ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The diagram depicts the versatile nature of MXenes showcasing their structural characteristics, and diverse applications in energy storage, electronics, sensors, catalysis, biomedical fields, and many more. MXenes, the most recent addition to the 2D material family, have attracted significant attention owing to their distinctive characteristics, including high surface area, conductivity, surface characteristics, mechanical strength, etc. This review begins by presenting MXenes, providing insights into their structural characteristics, synthesis methods, and surface functional groups. The review covers a thorough analysis of MXene surface properties, including surface chemistry and termination group impacts. The properties of MXenes are influenced by their synthesis, which can be fluorine-based or fluorine-dependent. Fluorine-based synthesis techniques involve etching with fluorine-based reagents, mainly including HF or LiF/HCl, while fluorine-free methods include electrochemical etching, chemical vapor deposition (CVD), alkaline etching, Lewis acid-based etching, etc. These techniques result in the emergence of functional groups such as –F, –O, –OH, –Cl, etc. on the MXenes surface, depending on the synthesis method used. Properties of MXenes, such as electrical conductivity, electronic properties, catalytic activity, magnetic properties, mechanical strength, and chemical and thermal stability, are examined, and the role of functional groups in determining these properties is explored. The review delves into the diverse applications of MXenes, encompassing supercapacitors, battery materials, hydrogen storage, fuel cells, electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding, pollutant removal, water purification, flexible electronics, sensors, additive manufacturing, catalysis, biomedical and healthcare fields, etc. Finally, this article outlines the challenges and opportunities in the current and future development of MXenes research, addressing various aspects such as synthesis scalability, etching challenges, and multifunctionality, and exploring novel applications. The review concludes with future prospects and conclusions envisioning the impact of MXenes on future technologies and innovation. Keywords MXenes 2D materials Surface chemistry MXenes structure Synthesis Applications 1 Introduction The world is constantly searching for solutions to address complex challenges in different fields such as electronics, energy, medicine, and environmental sustainability. As the demand for advanced materials grows, scientists and researchers are continuously exploring new frontiers including nanomaterials to discover materials with extraordinary properties and functionalities [1–7]. One such groundbreaking class of materials that has emerged in recent years is two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials. Since the discovery of 2D graphene in 2004, 2D materials have attained significant attention owing to their unparallel properties [8–12]. The family of 2D materials has expanded to include transition metal dichalcogenides [13–17], silicene [18–21], borophene [22–25], and black phosphorous (phosphorene) [26–28], further enriching this fascinating field of research. Other 2D materials like boron nitride (BN) and hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) [29–36] possess excellent thermal conductivity and electrical insulation, making them suitable for thermal management and protective coatings. The rise of 2D nanomaterials has spurred extensive research, driving exploration into inventive synthesis methods, in-depth property characterization, and varied applications in flexible electronics, energy storage, catalysis, and biomedical devices. Discovered in 2011 by Gogotsi and Barsoum from Drexel University (USA), MXenes play a pivotal role in this domain [37]. The general chemical formula for MXenes is M n +1X n T x which are derived from MAX phases, where M represents an early transition metal, X denotes carbon and/or nitrogen, T stands for surface functional groups (like –O, –OH, or –F), and n = 1, 2, 3, and 4 [38,39]. MXenes are obtained through a selective etching process, where the “A” layer (usually is aluminum, but it can be other elements like silicon or gallium) is removed from the MAX phase, a layered ternary compound composed of a transition metal (M), an element from Groups (13) and (14) (A), and carbon and/or nitrogen (X). By careful selective etching of the “A” element, the MXene material is obtained, leaving behind a 2D layered structure. Some of the key characteristics of MXenes include excellent electrical conductivity (∼20000 S cm−1), high surface area (∼200 m2 g−1), flexibility, and mechanical strength [40–47]. These properties, combined with their tunability through surface functionalization and composition variations, allow for their integration into diverse applications. Due to their high electrical conductivity and large surface area, MXene-based electrodes can provide faster charge–discharge rates and higher energy storage capacity than conventional 2D materials including graphene, etc. MXenes surpass graphene in various aspects, offering intrinsic hydrophilicity for better and stable dispersions, a tunable 2D structure with versatile surface chemistry, and superior metallic conductivity [48]. The ability of MXenes to accommodate diverse terminations, high transparency (transmitting >97%), hydrophilicity, etc. put MXenes ahead of other 2D materials in various aspects [49–51]. These unique attributes make MXenes a standout material, outperforming graphene in specific applications. The synthesis process typically involves immersing the MAX phase precursor in a suitable etchant solution. The most commonly used etchant is hydrofluoric acid (HF), the mixtures of hydrochloric acid (HCl) and lithium fluoride (LiF), LiF/HCl, bifluoride-based etchants like NH4HF2 or HF-containing salts, etc. [51,52]. Besides fluorine based synthesis approaches, MXene synthesis can be carried out using fluorine-free techniques including electrochemical etching [53], alkaline etching [54], Lewis acid-based etching [55], chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method [56], etc. The synthesis of MXenes induces various functional groups on MXenes, offering tunability for specific applications. HF or fluorine-based etchants yields mostly –F, in addition to some –O and –OH terminated MXenes, while fluorine-free etchants result in –O, –OH, and –Cl terminations [51]. Surface functional groups play a critical role in determining the properties and application of MXenes [51]. For instance, –OH-terminated MXenes exhibit improved energy storage, and –Cl from Lewis acidic salts optimizes electrochemical performance [57]. Fluorine-free methods overcome –F termination drawbacks, enhancing MXene conductivity and broadening applications [58–60]. The main advantage of fluorine-based MXene etchants is their high etching efficiency and selectivity [51]. However, their disadvantages include safety concerns due to harmful chemicals utilization, environmental concerns, and defects [61,62]. Fluorine-free MXene etching methods address these disadvantages, offering improved safety and handling [63]. However, the trade-off is a slightly milder etching efficiency and relatively low MXenes yield [62]. However, some methods can offer purity up to 92% [54]. MXenes can effectively attenuate and absorb electromagnetic radiation, making them valuable materials for electronic devices, aerospace applications, and military technologies [64,65]. Due to their unique surface chemistry and active sites, MXenes can be utilized as catalyst supports or directly as catalysts in various chemical reactions [66]. Their high surface area facilitates greater exposure of active sites, promoting catalytic efficiency and selectivity [67]. Their large surface area and chemical reactivity make them effective adsorbents for removing pollutants, heavy metals, and organic compounds from water sources [68,69]. The hydrophilic MXenes find applications in water purification, humidity sensors, inks, and as additives in composites to improve their interfacial adhesion and dispersion in water-based solutions [70–72]. Whether used in gas sensors, biosensors, or environmental monitoring devices, MXenes hold significant promise for advancing sensing technologies. Herein, we present a comprehensive review encompassing MXenes, delving into their structure, synthesis methods, surface characteristics, the impact of surface groups on fundamental properties, and their applications spanning energy storage and conversion, environmental remediation, electronics, optoelectronics, catalysis, and biomedicine. The adaptability and versatility of MXenes position them as a highly promising material class with extensive potential across diverse scientific and technological domains. Scheme 1 provides an overview of MXenes, their structure, fundamental properties, synthesis methods, surface characteristics, and applications across diverse domains [53,64,73–78]. 2 MXenes structure MXenes have a layered structure composed of transition metal layers sandwiched between carbon and/or nitrogen layers. As of now, MXenes (M n +1X n T x , n = 1–4) encompass transition metals from Groups (3)–(6), where M represents the metal element. X can be either carbon or nitrogen, and T denotes the various surface terminations. These terminations include elements from groups (16) and (17) of the periodic table, primarily comprising –O, –F, –Cl, etc., as well as hydroxyl groups (–OH) (Fig. 1 ). Recent advancements in the field of MXenes have led to an exciting discovery: oxygen substitution in carbide MXenes, resulting in the formation of oxycarbides [79,80]. This groundbreaking finding expands the possibilities of X, now encompassing oxygen as well. The incorporation of oxygen introduces new prospects for tailoring MXene properties and opens avenues for novel applications in various fields. Among the MXenes, Ti3C2T x has been extensively studied and remains the most well-known member of this family. MXenes exhibit a remarkable combination of properties, including high electrical conductivity, significant hydrophilicity, advantageous electrochemical characteristics, tunable band gap, and substantial surface area [61,81–86]. This unique set of attributes enables MXenes to be highly versatile and find extensive applications in various fields such as energy storage, fuel cells, photodetectors, sensors, conductive ink, three-dimensional (3D) printing, smart windows, and electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding [87–95]. Among the MXene family, Ti3C2T x , the titanium carbide MXene, stands out as the most sought-after member due to its exceptional properties, including high electrical conductivity, thermal stability, and outstanding mechanical strength [48,96]. In addition to Ti3C2T x , the MXene family comprises a diverse array of potential members, including Ti2CT x , V2CT x , Nb2CT x , Mo2CT x , and numerous others [89–91,97–103]. These MXenes are derived from various metal carbides, nitrides, and carbonitrides, each presenting a wide range of properties and promising applications. These different MXenes offer a rich pool of opportunities for tailoring their characteristics to suit specific requirements and applications. As researchers delve deeper into understanding and harnessing the potential of each MXene, the family continues to unveil its diverse and unique properties, propelling the exploration of novel applications in diverse areas, as evidenced by recent studies and investigations spanning a wide range of disciplines [65,104–106]. Besides the well-known MXenes discussed above, other MXenes such as (Ti,V)2CT x , (Ti,Nb)2CT x , (V,Nb)2CT x , etc. also exist [107]. These alternative MXenes, formed by different combinations of transition metals (M) and carbon/nitrogen (X), offer precise control over MXene properties. Recently, high-entropy M4C3T x MXenes, such as TiVNbMoC3T x and TiVCrMoC3T x , have been reported. Additionally, their precursors, high-entropy MAX phases (TiVNbMoAlC3 and TiVCrMoAlC3), have also been reported [108]. These novel high-entropy MXenes and MAX phases exhibit unique properties and hold great potential for various applications. Besides these, other MXenes and MAX phases with higher M or mixed X (C and N) are also reported [109–113]. More details about the existing MXenes are given in Fig. 2 . 3 Synthesis of MXenes The synthesis of MXenes holds significant importance due to their unique properties and versatile applications. The distinctive 2D structures of MXenes, resulting from precise etching of MAX phases, contribute to their exceptional conductivity, mechanical strength, and electrochemical properties [58–60,114]. As discussed earlier, the traditional synthesis of MXenes relies on the use of fluorine-based acids as etchants. However, the fluorine-based etchants are highly corrosive and hazardous substances, posing inherent risks to researchers' safety and requiring specialized equipment and facilities [115]. To address these challenges, new synthesis methods have been suggested, eliminating the reliance on fluorine-based etchants and introducing a fluorine-free era in MXene synthesis [116]. MXenes can also be etched using alkaline etchants, such as sodium hydroxide (NaOH), potassium hydroxide (KOH), lithium hydroxide (LiOH), etc. [54]. 3.1 Fluorine-acids based MXenes etching The process begins with the preparation of the MAX phase precursor, which is often obtained through powder metallurgy techniques. MXenes are synthesized through a top-down etching method that involves the selective removal of “A” atomic layers from MAX phases using etchants such as HF, LiF/HCl, bifluoride-based etchants (NH4HF2), or HF-containing salts [73]. This etching process transforms layered MAX phase powders into multilayered MXenes having accordion like structures. The etched MXene layers can be exfoliated using minimally intensive layer delamination (MILD) process with minimal chemical and mechanical intervention [51,61]. The multilayered MXenes can also be intercalated with metal cations, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH), etc. This intercalation step facilitates the separation of individual MXene flakes and enhances the exfoliation process [39,51,117]. After intercalation, the mixture undergoes sonication, which assists in the delamination of MXene flakes from the multilayered structure. As a result of this process, delaminated single-flake MXenes are obtained, where individual MXene flakes are dispersed in a liquid medium (Fig. 3 ). These delaminated MXene flakes offer unique properties and functionalities that are desirable in applications in advanced materials, energy storage, catalysis, and biomedical fields. The ability to control the synthesis and delamination process allows for precise tuning of MXene properties, making them versatile and valuable materials for various cutting-edge technologies. 3.2 Fluorine-free MXenes etching Fluorine-free MXenes etching methods encompass a range of approaches, such as electrochemical etching, molten salt etching driven by Lewis acids, alkaline/hydrothermal techniques, CVD, and various other pioneering methodologies. These innovative approaches not only address safety and environmental concerns but also offer the potential for scalable and sustainable MXene production. 3.2.1 Electrochemical etching method Fluorine-free electrochemical method for etching MXenes uses an aqueous electrolyte to obtain high-yield MXenes nanosheets [118]. This approach offers versatility in customizing MXene properties and creating precise surface patterns. The preparation method entails the controlled voltage-driven selective elimination of the A-layer, utilizing a MAX phase as an electrode [119,120]. This method can also be extended to the etching of other MXenes [120]. During the anode etching process, the Cl− ions etch the Al atomic layer, and NH4OH intercalation facilitates the peeling out of MXene edges from the anode surface. After the electrochemical elimination of aluminum from MAX phase, e.g., Ti2AlC, the resulting MXene is endowed with –Cl terminal groups. The reaction taking place (Eq. (1)) on the Ti2AlC working electrode is depicted as [120]. (1) Ti2AlC + yCl− + (2x + z)H2O → Ti2C(OH)2 x Cl y O z + Al3+ + (x + z)H2 + (y + 3)e− At the counter electrode Pt, the reaction (Eq. (2)) occurs as (2) Al3+ + 3e− → Al Since this method prohibits the use of F-containing agents, the resulting MXenes flakes are –O and –HO terminated rather than F– terminated, which remarkably enhances their capacitance for supercapacitor applications. 3.2.2 Lewis acidic etching Fluoride-free etching using Lewis acids represents another important MXene synthesis technique, offering an alternative to conventional fluorine-based methods while maintaining control over the MXenes properties and structure for tailored applications [55]. This approach is employed to selectively etch MAX phases by facilitating a direct redox coupling between the A element (typically Al, Si, or Ga) and the cation of the Lewis acid molten salt (Fig. 4 b) [121]. In a molten state, transition metal halides display reactivity with the A layer of MAX phases owing to their electron-accepting characteristics. A MAX phase can be etched in molten salt environments as presented by Eqs. (3) and (4) as follows [122]. (3) T i 3 A l C 2 + 3 2 C u C l 2 N a C l / K C l → T i 3 C 2 + A l C l 3 ( g ) ↑ + ( 3 2 ) C u (4) T i 3 C 2 + C u C l 2 N a C l / K C l → T i 3 C 2 C l 2 + C u Lewis acid-assisted etching offers precise control, and molten salt etching of MXenes, achieved by subjecting MXene films or sheets to controlled salt compositions and temperatures, allows selective layer removal. 3.2.3 Alkali-etched MXenes synthesis Another fluorine-free etching method to synthesize MXenes is hydrothermal alkali etching using different alkalis agents [54] (Fig. 4c). The possibility of utilizing alkali as a viable alternative for the selective etching of the MAX phase is remarkable. When the concentration of alkali and the temperature are raised beyond a particular threshold, notable transformations take place in the character of the reaction between alkali and the MAX phase. These fluorine-free etching methods offer promising alternatives for the synthesis of high-purity MXene materials, providing enhanced performance for various applications, particularly in supercapacitors where high capacitance and stability are essential. The interaction between the alkali agent (NaOH) and MAX phase (Ti3AlC2) experiences a significant transformation, resulting in the formation of etched MXene. This optimized method yields an exceptional yield of MXene (Ti3C2T x ) by the reaction mechanism given by Eqs. (5) and (6) as [54] (5) Ti3AlC2 + OH− + 5H2O → Ti3C2(OH)2 + Al(OH)− 4 + 2.5H2 ↑ (6) Ti3AlC2 + OH− + 5H2O → Ti3C2O2 + Al(OH)− 4 + 3.5H2 ↑ The resulting MXenes, free from –F terminal groups, lead to electrodes with significantly enhanced mass-specific capacitance when prepared through this method, surpassing the performance of multilayer MXenes prepared with HF by an impressive 214% [54]. 3.2.4 Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) An alternative method for MXene synthesis involves CVD. This direct synthetic route allows for scalable and atom-economic production of MXenes, including those that have not been previously synthesized from MAX phases [74]. The process involves reactions between metals or metal halides and graphite, methane, or nitrogen. Ti2CCl2 MXene can be synthesized through a high-temperature reaction involving Ti, graphite, and TiCl4 as precursors. To initiate the synthesis, titanium and graphite were carefully ground into a fine powder in a molar ratio of 3:1.8. Subsequently, 1.1 mol TiCl4 was added to the mixture. The resulting mixture was then sealed in a quartz ampoule and subjected to heating. The temperature was ramped up to 950 °C within 20 min and maintained at this level until the reaction reached completion. In this method, the reaction duration of approximately 2 h is sufficient to achieve the maximum yield of MXene (Fig. 4d). In addition to the methods mentioned earlier, there are other techniques for MXene synthesis, such as sputtering, pulse laser plasma deposition, UV-induced etching, mechanochemical etching, thermal reduction etching, hydrogen halide etching, thermal treatment-based approaches, halogen-based etching, etc. [123–127]. 4 MXene surface chemistry and its significance The surface chemistry of MXenes is particularly significant, as it underpins their unique properties and potential applications. To fully harness the potential of MXenes, understanding and manipulating their surface chemistry becomes crucial, allowing researchers to optimize properties and explore novel functionalities of these materials. As discussed earlier, MXenes possess a diverse array of surface terminations, including –OH, –O, –Cl, or –F (Fig. 5 a), arising from the etching process during their synthesis [128,129]. These terminations have a profound impact on the MXenes surface chemistry, stability, and interactions with other materials, underscoring their uniqueness and versatility in various applications [130,131]. Various techniques are employed for the synthesis and delamination of MXenes, leading to diverse outcomes in surface chemistry, interlayer spacing, flake dimensions, and defect density. The choice of etching method significantly influences surface chemistry. Most reported MXenes are synthesized using wet-chemical etching in HF or HF-containing/forming etchants. This process introduces surface functionalities like –O, –F, or –OH. Similarly, LiF/HCl based etchants introduce additional –Cl groups in addition to –O, –F, or –OH terminations [51,132,133]. nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) serves as a valuable tool for quantifying surface terminations in Ti3C2T x MXene with –OH and –F terminations [134]. Interestingly, even after vacuum drying at 200 °C, H2O is detected persisting between the Ti3C2T x sheets. Quantitative NMR experiments highlight a significant disparity in the abundance of –OH terminations compared to –F and –O terminations. The MXenes synthesis method significantly influences the sensitivity of the surface termination. The MXenes synthesized using HF have nearly four times more –F terminations compared to the material synthesized with LiF/HCl. Raman spectroscopy serves as a valuable tool for tracking surface groups [135,136]. The Raman spectrum reveals distinct regions for Ti3C2T x MXenes etched by LiF/HCl (Fig. 5b). The first region indicates resonant peak, coupled with the plasmonic peak. The flake region covers in-plane and out-of-plane vibrations of titanium atoms, carbon, and surface groups. Subsequently, the 230–470 cm−1 range represents in-plane vibrations (Eg) of surface groups (T x ) attached to titanium atoms, exclusively influenced by surface atoms, and promising for probing MXene surface chemistry. The 580–730 cm−1 region is predominantly attributed to carbon vibrations, offering a fingerprinting tool for surface groups in various in situ electrochemical studies. The synthesis of MXenes in acid solutions containing F-ions typically offers limited control over terminations [133]. The surface predominantly exhibits –F and –O/–OH terminations (Fig. 5c), with the modulation of –F terminations achievable by adjusting acid concentrations. Moreover, the complete removal of –F terminations, replaced by –O/–OH terminations, can be achieved through treatment with a base such as NaOH or TBAOH [122,137]. In molten salt environments, the cations undergo a Lewis acid-base reaction with the A layer, initially replaced by Zn. Subsequent deintercalation of Zn results in MXenes with unary –Cl terminations [121] (Fig. 5c). Manipulating the composition of the molten salt used for MAX phase etching allows for attaching various halogen terminations in desired stoichiometries to the MXene surface. Notably, beyond halogens (–Cl, –Br, and –I), diverse terminations such as –S, –Se, –Te, –P, and –Sb can be uniformly applied to MXenes. By heating MXenes in different gases, uniform –O and –C terminations are attainable. The molten salt method described earlier facilitates the synthesis of –Cl or –Br terminated MXenes (e.g., Ti3C2Cl2, Ti3C2Br2, and, Nb2CBr2), which can serve as templates for post-synthesis MXenes terminated with –S, –Se, –Te, –NH, and –O, as well as bare or –H-terminated MXenes [114]. MXene surface groups tend to occupy specific crystallographic sites, as illustrated in Fig. 5(d). There are four theoretically possible termination sites for MXenes [133]. Taking Ti3C2T z as an example, when terminations are positioned directly above the middle Ti atoms (pink atoms in Fig. 3), they occupy FCC sites on the top and bottom Ti layers (Fig. 5d). Placing surface groups directly above the surface Ti atoms results in the “top” configuration (Fig. 5d). If the surface termination atoms are situated directly above the C atoms, they occupy hexagonal close-packed (HCP) sites concerning the surface Ti atoms (Fig. 5d). When surface groups occupy a position between the Ti atoms that is not defined by FCC or HCP, it is termed a “bridge” configuration (Fig. 5d). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations indicate that FCC positions are the most favorable. These observations reveal that the majority of terminations occupy FCC positions. During MXene synthesis, the nature of these surface terminations can be modified to tailor the surface chemistry, providing a means to customize MXene properties [138]. For example, the Ti3C2 monolayer is found to exhibit magnetic metal behavior, while Ti3C2F2 and Ti3C2(OH)2, in stable conformations, showed semiconductor characteristics with small band gaps [139] The presence of surface terminations helps in various types of functionalization, where specific chemical groups can be attached to the MXene surface to introduce tailored functionalities, enhancing interactions with other materials for specific applications [138,140,141]. The MXenes surface chemistry significantly influences its solubility and interactions with solvents [135,138,140–142]. While MXenes are generally insoluble in common organic solvents, they display excellent dispersibility in water-based solutions due to their hydrophilic nature [143–145]. This solubility behavior allows for convenient solution processing techniques and the fabrication of MXene-based films, coatings, and composites. Additionally, the functional groups on the MXene surface facilitate charge transfer and redox reactions, making MXenes an ideal choice for use in batteries, supercapacitors, and electrocatalysis [60,146]. The surface chemistry tunability further amplifies the exceptional attributes of MXenes, offering endless possibilities for innovative applications and cutting-edge advancements across various scientific and technological domains. 5 Properties of MXenes MXenes are known for their exceptional properties. They exhibit high electrical conductivity, excellent mechanical strength, and significant thermal conductivity [147–149]. MXenes are prone to oxidation in the presence of moist air and water, yet their chemical stability can be customized through specific treatments under various conditions [150–153]. Additionally, they possess efficient electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding capabilities due to high electrical conductivity and, when properly functionalized, they show promise for biomedical applications [64,154] Theoretical predictions suggest that most non-terminated MXenes exhibit magnetic character, specifically observed in Ti n +1X n (X = C, N) monolayers due to the presence of 3d electrons in surface Ti atoms [155]. These unique properties have sparked extensive research, leading to potential advancements in electronics, energy storage, catalysis, and other cutting-edge technologies [38]. 5.1 Electrical conductivity MXenes, such as Ti3C2T x and V2CT x , exhibit exceptional electrical conductivity, rivaling that of graphene [40]. This high conductivity is attributed to the presence of metallic transition metal layers, which allow for efficient charge transport [147,156]. The remarkable electrical properties of MXenes make them suitable for electronic and energy-related applications. They are used as conductive electrodes in supercapacitors and batteries, where their high surface area and conductivity enhance charge storage and device performance. Moreover, their application extends to flexible electronics, wearable devices, and electromagnetic interference shielding. Also, F-terminated MXenes have low electrical conductivity as compared to their O-terminated counterparts. Additionally, the NH2-terminated MXenes exhibit the electrical conductivity [157]. 5.2 Electronic properties MXenes without surface terminations exhibit metallic behavior, primarily due to the high density of states (DOS) near the Fermi level, driven by the abundant d electrons of transition metals [158]. However, during experimental synthesis, the introduction of surface terminations becomes challenging to precisely control in terms of number and type. The incorporation of surface terminations induces a notable alteration in the MXene band structure resulting in semiconducting character in MXenes [158]. The hybridization between the p orbital of the termination group and the d orbital of the transition metal leads to a reduction in the peak density of states, resulting in the formation of a band gap. This shift elevates the d orbital above the Fermi level, causing a transition in MXene properties from metal to semiconductor. Additionally, a larger atomic number of the transition metal (M) generally corresponds to a larger band gap value. Consequently, both the MAX phase and MXenes undergo a transformation into semiconductor behavior upon the introduction of termination groups. DFT calculations using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) and Heyd-Scuseria-Ernzerhof (HSE06) methods reveal that Ti2X and MAX phases exhibit metallic properties, whereas the density of states of Ti2XT2 with surface terminations significantly decreases at the Fermi level [155]. PBE and HSE06 functions produce similar results, indicating metallic behavior for most materials except Ti2CO2. While PBE predicts a 0.24 eV band gap for Ti2CO2, HSE06 suggests a wider 0.88 eV gap, implying a near 1 eV band gap. Removal of Al from MAX phases shifts the Fermi energy down, and further energy descent occurs after terminating MXene surfaces (Fig. 6 a and b). The electronic properties of Ti3C2 layers are strongly influenced by surface terminations. The bare Ti3C2 monolayer (Fig. 6c) exhibits metallic behavior with split spin-up and spin-down channels, turning into metallicity with substantial electron states at the Fermi level [139]. Ti3C2F2 and Ti3C2 (OH)2 monolayers, resulting from termination with F and OH, display versatile conducting characteristics. Depending on the spatial arrangements of surface F and OH groups, they can act as narrow-band gap semiconductors or metals. I-Ti3C2F2 (Fig. 6d) and III-Ti3C2F2 (Fig. 6f) exhibit semiconducting states with narrow band gaps, while II-Ti3C2F2 (Fig. 6e) behaves as a metal. I-Ti3C2(OH)2 (Fig. 6g) shows a semiconducting character, while III-Ti3C2(OH)2 (Fig. 6i) maintains semiconducting behavior with a narrow band gap. However, II-Ti3C2(OH)2 (Fig. 6h) behaves as a metallic system. Thus, surface functional groups and their geometric arrangements can effectively modify the electronic properties of the Ti3C2 monolayer. The band structure and DOS of MXenes, investigated through DFT calculations, indicate that the Fermi energy of the pristine MXene shifts down compared to the MAX phase precursor, and this shift is further amplified after introducing surface terminations [155,158,159]. The density of states at the Fermi level, N(E f), is predominantly governed by the Ti 3d orbitals of the MAX phases. The valence states below the Fermi level exhibited a division into two distinct sub-bands: band A, consisting of hybridized orbitals Ti 3d–C 2p and Ti 3d–Al 3s, and band B, comprising Ti 3d–Al 3p orbitals. Upon the removal of Al atoms, both bands A and B were observed to be narrowed. Notably, the N(E f) shows an increase from 1.88 to 3.15 eV for the conversion of Ti2AlC to Ti2C, and from 2.77 to 4.84 eV for the conversion of Ti2AlN to Ti2N. This change is attributed to the breaking of Ti–Al bonds during the transformation [155]. Surface terminations and M elements play a crucial role in shaping the electronic properties of MXenes. For instance, Ti3C2(OH)2 exhibits a bandgap of 0.05 eV, while Ti3C2F2 demonstrates a slightly larger bandgap of 0.1 eV. These variations highlight the significant impact of surface terminations and the M element on the electronic characteristics of MXenes [37]. The substitution of Ti with Mo atoms in the outer layers of Ti3C2 and Ti4C3 MXenes demonstrated a transition from metallic to semiconducting behavior [160]. Additionally, it was predicted that Zr2CO2 would possess a bandgap of 0.88 eV, while Hf2CO2 would exhibit a slightly larger bandgap of 1 eV. Notably, oxygen functionalized M2C MXenes, where M represents W, Mo, and Cr, as well as some ordered double transition metals MXenes with the configuration M′2M″C2 (where M′ can be Mo or W, and M″ can be Ti, Zr, or Hf), have been suggested to display topological insulator properties [161]. The electronic conductivity of MXenes (Ti2C) can be enhanced through an alloy engineering strategy at transition metal sites [162]. Theoretical calculations on the solid-solution TiNbC MXene indicate improved electronic conductivity, an upward shift in the d-band center, tailored surface functional groups, and increased electron loss impedance. These modifications contribute to its exceptional capacitive performance and heightened chemical stability. 5.3 Energy storage properties Electrochemical properties, such as electronic/ionic conductivity and hydrophily, as well as energy storage performance, are significantly influenced by the nature of surface terminal groups. For instance, surface groups like –F and –OH can hinder ion transport, leading to a reduction in electrochemical capacity [163]. Consequently, the optimization of MXenes electrode performance relies heavily on adjusting the content and distribution of these surface functional groups. Following K+ intercalation and removal of terminal groups (OH–/F–), the intercalation pseudocapacitance triples compared to the pristine MXene to 211% of the original gravimetric capacitance. This enhanced electrochemical performance is ascribed to the extensive interlayer voids in Ti3C2 and the minimal concentration of terminated surface groups. Contrary to –F terminations, –O groups provide more pseudocapacitance active sites [164]. To address the issue of –F termination and circumvent the negative effects associated with –F groups, researchers are exploring fluoride-free synthesis methods for MXenes to enhance the electrochemical performance of MXenes electrodes by mitigating the presence of undesirable surface groups. The elimination of –F terminal groups on MXenes can be achieved through a reaction with Na metal at high temperatures [165]. Subsequently, abundant –O terminal groups were introduced through successive reactions with atomic-scale alkali metal and water. In Fig. 7 (a), cyclic voltammetry (CV) and galvanostatic charge discharge (GCD) curves compare Ti3C2T x and Ti3C2T x -Na electrodes, with Fig. 7(c) showcasing scan rate-dependent CV curves for Ti3C2T x -Na. The Ti3C2T x -Na electrode demonstrates a capacitive storage mechanism, dominant intercalation pseudocapacitance, and additional capacitance in the oxidative and reductive peak ranges (Fig. 7d). Nyquist plots for Ti3C2T x -Na electrode display a higher slope in the low-frequency region, attributed to the removal of –F terminal groups that may hinder ion transport. Importantly, the Ti3C2T x -Na electrode exhibits a GCD curve similar to Ti3C2T x and retains over 92% of its capacity after 10,000 cycles (Fig. 7e), demonstrating excellent cycle stability. Despite a quick reduction in surface redox pseudocapacitance at higher scan rates due to the replacement of –F by –O providing more active sites (Fig. 7f), the Ti3C2T x -Na electrode maintains higher performance than Ti3C2T x . DFT calculations are conducted to understand the reaction mechanism between Ti3C2T x and atomic-scale sodium. The binding energy of different surface terminal groups (–O, –OH, and –F) of Ti3C2T x with the Na atom at the hollow site, considered the most stable binding position, is assessed. As illustrated in Fig. 7(g), the –F terminal exhibits a relatively larger binding energy with Na (–0.84 eV). Consequently, during the annealing process, Na atoms are expected to be adsorbed on the –F terminal, as indicated by Eq. (7) given as [165]. (7) Ti3C2F x + yNa → Ti3C2F x − y (FNa) y Subsequently, in the washing step with the aid of water, the following reaction (Eq. (8)) occurs, facilitating the replacement of –F by –O. (8) Ti3C2F x − y (FNa) y + yH2O → Ti3C2F x − y O y + yNaF + yH2 This assumption finds support in the reduction of the Gibbs free energy (ΔG) to −1.80 eV for the second-step reaction. DFT calculations revealed that surface functionalization with –F and –OH groups impedes lithium transport, leading to a significant reduction in Li storage capacity. The storage capacity decreases from 320 mA h g−1 for bare Ti3C2 to 130 mA h g−1 for Ti3C2F2 and further to 67 mA h g−1 for Ti3C2(OH)2 [139]. To enhance electrochemical performance, the hydrogen annealing method can be employed to eliminate the –F termination from the surface of Ti3C2 [60]. 5.4 Catalytic properties of MXenes The catalytic properties of MXenes, arising from their unique surface chemistry and electronic structure, make them versatile candidates for various catalytic applications [166]. MXenes exhibit notable catalytic activity in reactions such as hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen reduction (ORR), and other redox processes [167,168]. O-/OH-terminated MXenes are preferred for the HER as the O atoms serve as active sites with strong interaction capabilities for H radicals. DFT calculations indicate that the Gibbs free energy of O-terminated MXenes adsorbing atomic H is close to 0, suggesting their suitable affinity with H radicals and facilitating easy hydrogen desorption due to moderate O–H interaction [169,170]. Although fluorine-termination can enhance proton adsorption kinetics, it deteriorates conductivity. MXenes etched by common HF methods unavoidably result in –F inert groups replacing –O groups, leading to a reduction in active sites and conductivity. For improvement, these can be hybridized with MoS2, etc. [59]. The impact of terminal groups on the HER performance is illustrated in Fig. 8 through a volcano curve, which compares the HER performance of 2D MXenes with and without oxygen termination [170]. To assess the theoretical exchange current, i 0, calculations of the average Gibbs free energies of hydrogen adsorption (ΔG H* a) were conducted for both bare 2D MXenes and oxygen-terminated MXenes. The positioning of I 0 and ΔG H* a values relative to the volcano peak provides a quantitative evaluation of the HER performance. Catalysts with negative ΔG H* a values are situated on the left leg of the volcano, while those with positive values are on the right leg. Catalysts with ΔG H* a close to zero are located at the peak. Non-terminal MXenes exhibit robust hydrogen interactions with notably large negative ΔG H* a values less than −0.73 eV, leading to a low exchange current positioned at the bottom of the left leg. In contrast, oxygen termination proves beneficial as it optimizes ΔG H* a by weakening hydrogen interactions (ΔG H* a ∼0), thereby facilitating hydrogen release and achieving a high exchange current. Among the oxygen-terminated MXenes, Ti2CO2, with a ΔG H* a of only 0.01 eV, is anticipated to exhibit the most favorable HER performance, followed closely by Ti3C2O2 and Nb2CO2. This analysis provides valuable insights into the role of terminal groups in shaping the HER performance of 2D MXenes, shedding light on potential optimizations for enhanced catalytic activity. 5.5 Magnetic properties Theoretical predictions indicate that MXenes exhibit unique magnetic properties and most of MXenes without terminal groups exhibit magnetism. In pure or non-terminated MXenes, only the Ti n +1X n (X = C, N) monolayers exhibit magnetism, attributed to the presence of 3d electrons in the surface Ti atoms [155]. However, introducing surface terminations can dramatically change these magnetic characteristics. Ti3C2T x and Ti4C3T x , initially magnetic, may become non-magnetic after surface termination. Cr2CT x maintains ferromagnetism with –OH and –F terminations but loses it with –O terminations [171]. In contrast, Mn2NT x remains ferromagnetic irrespective of surface termination. V2C shifts from an antiferromagnetic metal to a small bandgap antiferromagnetic semiconductor with –F or –OH termination. Cr2C, a ferromagnetic semi-metal, transforms into an antiferromagnetic semiconductor with –F, –Cl, –OH, or –H end groups. Cr2N, with more valence electrons than Cr2C, becomes semi-metallic with –F, –O, or –OH surfaces [158]. Ta3C2 MXene also exhibits the ferromagnetic character [172]. V2C monolayers exhibit antiferromagnetic behavior, while V2N monolayers are nonmagnetic metals [173]. However, with –F or –OH functionalization, V2C transforms into a small-gap antiferromagnetic semiconductor [174]. Some magnetic MXenes become nonmagnetic due to the formation of p–d bonds between surface transition metal atoms and end groups. Asymmetric surface termination in MXenes, like Cr2CFCl, Cr2CHF, Cr2CFOH, and V2CFOH, results in antiferromagnetic semiconductors. Sc2CTT′ (T, T′ = –H, –O, –OH, –F, and –Cl) with different asymmetric combinations exhibits ferromagnetic ordered semi-metals if they contain –O, while others are non-magnetic semiconductors. The tunability of termination allows MXenes to showcase diverse magnetic properties, broadening their potential applications in the realm of magnetism. As confirmed by DFT calculations, Ti2MnC2T x , Hf2MnC2T x , and Hf2VC2T x (T = F, OH, and O) MXene monolayers exhibit intrinsic ferromagnetism. Ti2MnC2T x remains a ferromagnetic semimetallic-metallic system regardless of surface terminations, while Hf2MnC2O2 and Hf2VC2O2 monolayers are ferromagnetic semiconductors [175]. These MXene structures are inherently ferromagnetic without modifications, showing potential for crystalline synthesis. With Curie temperatures surpassing room temperature, they hold promise for applications. In-plane strains induce transitions in their magnetic and electronic properties, making them essential for next-gen spintronic devices. In Fig. 9 (b and c), the calculated partial DOS of Ti2MnC2O2 monolayer for nonmagnetic and magnetic phases is depicted. In the nonmagnetic phase (Fig. 9b), Mn-3d (t2g) states dominate energy bands around the Fermi level (EF), with contributions from other elements aligning with the schematic in Fig. 9(a). Transitioning to the ferromagnetic phase (Fig. 9c), the magnetic exchange field separates up-spin and down-spin bands, particularly impacting half-occupied t2g states. The up-spin t2g states shift below E F by 2–6 eV, while down-spin t2g states rise to 2–4 eV above E F, with all t2g states contributing equally to ferromagnetism. The calculated magnetic moment (μ) for the ferromagnetic phase is 2.97 μB/unit cell, consistent with the model prediction. The origin of μ is attributed to the spin polarization of Mn4+ d electrons in the middle layer, visible in the spin density map (Fig. 9d). Analyzing the electronic and magnetic properties of Ti2MnC2O2, the extension to other termination groups (–OH and –F) in the Ti2MnC2T x MXene family, reveals a ferromagnetic ground state with higher spontaneous magnetic moments. In this analysis, Ti cations assume a 3+ oxidation state (Fig. 9e), and the Ti3+ d electron couples to Mn4+ d electrons through Ti–C–Mn bonds. Two scenarios arise. In the nonmagnetic phase (Fig. 9f), the Ti3+ d electron hops to half-filled t2g states, while in the ferromagnetic phase (Fig. 9g), it couples to eg states, aligning ferromagnetically with d electrons at t2g states. The actual ground state lies between these, with μ = 3.90 μB/unit cell in the ferromagnetic phase of Ti2MnC2(OH)2. The Ti3+ contribution to the total magnetic moment is visible in the spin density map (Fig. 9h), but the magnetic moment per Ti3+ (0.45 μB/unit cell) is smaller than predicted, suggesting coupling to both t2g and eg states of Mn4+. The up-spin and down-spin bands derived from Ti d electrons are not completely segregated in energy and are both partially occupied at E F (Fig. 9g). 5.6 Mechanical strength Another notable property of MXenes is their remarkable mechanical strength. The strong covalent bonds within the 2D layers, combined with weak van der Waals interactions between the layers, contribute to their mechanical robustness [41,176]. MXenes have been utilized as reinforcing additives in composite materials to enhance mechanical properties, such as tensile strength and toughness. The incorporation of MXenes into polymers, metals, and ceramics results in composites with improved mechanical performance, making them valuable for structural and engineering applications. Oxygen-terminated MXenes, particularly, M4X3, exhibit remarkable mechanical characteristics comparable to graphene [177]. Moreover, the carbides display higher structural stability compared to nitrides. The strength of M−O bonding primarily governs the mechanical robustness of M4X3O2 MXene. 5.7 Thermal conductivity Certain MXenes, like Ti3C2T x , exhibit high thermal conductivity, an important property for effective heat dissipation. MXenes are employed as thermal interface materials in electronic devices to enhance heat transfer and dissipate excess heat [178–180]. Improved thermal management leads to increased device efficiency, reduced risk of overheating, and extended device lifespan. Their applications extend to industries where efficient heat dissipation is critical, such as aerospace, automotive, and electronics. 5.8 Chemical and thermal stability MXenes are known for their rapid oxidation when exposed to moist air and water. However, their chemical stability under various conditions can be tailored by additional treatments [150–153]. The stability also depends upon the functional groups on MXenes surface [153,181]. Reducing the number of –OH terminations through hydrogen annealing can effectively enhance the stability of MXene films. However, a drawback of this treatment is that the resulting film exhibits poor redispersibility in aqueous solutions, making it challenging to reprocess the material [182]. Their robustness allows them to withstand harsh environments and makes them suitable for anticorrosive applications [183]. Functionalized MXenes have shown promise in water purification, where they can remove pollutants and heavy metals due to their chemical stability and large surface area. Additionally, their chemical stability has made them efficient catalysts for various chemical reactions, contributing to advancements in catalysis and energy conversion [184,185]. MXenes are thermally stable up to 800 °C. However, under an Ar atmosphere, Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets exhibit higher thermal stability, remaining stable up to 1200 °C [186]. In an Ar atmosphere, Ti3C2 MXene with F/OH termination demonstrates stability at temperatures up to 800 °C, while MXene with Cl terminations remains stable up to 750 °C [187]. The oxygen-terminated MXenes (e.g., Ti3C2O2) exhibit superior thermodynamic stability compared to hydroxyl- and fluorine-terminated MXenes [188]. This enhanced stability is attributed to the oxygen groups hindering the deformation of the Ti–C structure, whereas other terminating species lead to bond instability modes. In addition to the mentioned approaches, several other strategies contribute to enhancing the oxidation stability of MXenes. These strategies encompass the application of antioxidants [189], dispersion in organic solvents, colloidal suspensions within nonpolar solvents [145], surface passivation etc. [176,190,191]. Incorporating MXenes into nanocomposites with other materials is another measure to protect these against oxidation [64,192,193]. Furthermore, optimizing MXene synthesis conditions, such as pH, temperature, etc., plays a crucial role in influencing their intrinsic resistance to oxidation [152,194]. 5.9 Biocompatibility Some MXenes, when appropriately functionalized, have shown biocompatibility, making them promising candidates for biomedical applications. Functionalized MXenes can be used in drug delivery systems, where they act as carriers to transport therapeutics to specific targets with reduced side effects [195–197]. Their biocompatibility has possible applications in targeted drug delivery and biomedical imaging, offering potential solutions in the fields of medicine and healthcare. A halogen-free version MXenes are anticipated to have superior biocompatibility compared to the conventional fluorinated MXenes. NaOH-treated MXenes (or –OH/O terminated) display biocompatibility, unaffected by the degree of oxidation and even at elevated concentrations [198]. In contrast, the potential toxicity of MLID-MXenes may be linked to halogen species released during oxidative degradation. The halogen-free MXenes not only maintain biocompatibility at high concentrations but also exhibit resistance to oxidative degradation. 6 Applications of MXenes Due to their high surface area, electrical conductivity, and exceptional mechanical strength, MXenes are extensively investigated for supercapacitors, batteries, and fuel cells, revolutionizing energy storage technologies [199]. Moreover, their catalytic activity and unique electronic properties enable efficient catalysts for chemical reactions and water purification systems [200–202]. MXenes also exhibit outstanding sensing capabilities, making them suitable for environmental monitoring and healthcare diagnostics [203]. 6.1 EMI shielding applications MXenes exhibit excellent EMI shielding capabilities, making them attractive for electromagnetic compatibility applications. In EMI shielding applications, the surface terminations of MXenes play a crucial role by inducing dipolar polarization. HF-etched MXenes exhibit more –F terminations compared to LiF/HCl etchant, which leads to more –O terminated MXenes [204]. The O-terminated MXenes, known for better electrical conductivity, outperform the F-terminated counterparts. This superiority is attributed to higher electrical conductivity, a larger surface area, and enhanced conductive networks in LiF/HCl MXenes. The higher surface area of LiF/HCl etched MXenes, featuring numerous surface terminations and point defects, results in increased dipolar polarization loss and greater attenuation. By incorporating MXenes into coatings and composites, electronic devices can be protected from external electromagnetic interference, ensuring their proper functioning and data security [205–208]. The ability to shield against unwanted electromagnetic radiation has significant implications in electronics, telecommunications, and defense industries. EMI shielding is the most explored area among the applications of MXene-polymer nanocomposites. These composites offer several advantages in the field of EMI shielding [206,209,210]. MXenes offer a plethora of advantages in this field, including lightweight characteristics, high conductivity, and improved mechanical properties, which make them suitable for EMI shielding applications [210–212]. The tunability provided by polymers allows for customization of the EMI shielding performance to suit specific application requirements. By selecting appropriate polymers with specific dielectric properties, the overall electrical conductivity and impedance matching of the composite can be tailored for optimal shielding within desired frequency ranges [64,210,213]. Additionally, polymers in these composites contribute to chemical resistance and durability, acting as a protective layer for MXene flakes against environmental factors such as moisture, chemicals, or oxidation, thereby enhancing the longevity and performance of EMI shielding materials [214]. To achieve effective EMI shielding, materials with high electrical conductivity are typically required to attain significant EMI shielding effectiveness (SE) values. The incorporation of polymers into MXene composites results in enhanced tensile strength, while maintaining satisfactory conductivity even at low polymer loadings. Sodium alginate (SA) is a natural polymer that holds promise as an excellent choice for polymeric matrices. Its abundance, eco-friendliness, and mechanical resilience position SA as an ideal candidate for EMI shielding applications if introduced with MXenes (Fig. 10 a). Among the various MXenes, Ti3C2T x films exhibit the highest electrical conductivity [64] (Fig. 10b). This exceptional electrical conductivity is attributed to the elevated electron DOS near the Fermi level, as predicted by DFT, indicating the metallic nature of this particular MXene [158]. Conductivity increases as the MXene content increases (10–90 wt% Ti3C2T x ) in the sodium alginate polymer (SA) as shown in Fig. 10(c). Due to high conductivity, the Ti3C2T x exhibits the highest EMI SE (Fig. 10d). The EMI SE is thickness dependent as demonstrated in Fig. 10(e), where the 45 µm thick MXene film blocks >99% of incident radiation. MXene films exhibit outstanding EMI SE shielding capability across a wide frequency range and as the MXene content is increased, the EMI SE also increases, reaching a maximum of 57 dB in case of 90 wt% MXene (Ti3C2T x )-SA (Fig. 10f). In EMI shielding, absorption and reflection are two essential mechanisms that determine the overall effectiveness of the shielding material. When EMI waves interact with the material, the electrons in the material absorb the energy of the waves, leading to a dissipation of electromagnetic energy in the form of heat. This absorption process results in the weakening or blocking of the transmitted EMI waves, contributing to the shielding effectiveness. Reflection, on the other hand, occurs when EMI waves strike the surface of the shielding material and are reflected back in the opposite direction. In this case, the shielding material acts like a mirror, bouncing off the electromagnetic waves and preventing them from passing through to the other side. This reflection process reduces the intensity of EMI waves that can penetrate the shield. The EMI shielding mechanism at 8.2 GHz, for Ti3C2T x (6 μm) and 60 wt% Ti3C2T x -SA (∼8 μm) films, is shown in Fig. 10(g). It was observed that shielding due to absorption was the dominant mechanism in both pristine MXene and its composites. The high electrical conductivity and unique properties of MXenes make them highly effective in absorbing EMI waves and converting them into heat energy, resulting in superior EMI shielding capabilities. MXene composite aerogels, incorporating cellulose nanofibers and surface encapsulated with fire-retardant thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU), showcase impressive EMI shielding characteristics [215]. With MXene content of 3.14 wt%, these aerogels exhibit an exceptionally high EMI shielding effectiveness of 93.5 dB. Furthermore, they achieve a threefold utilization efficiency of MXene as compared to values reported in previous studies. For effective EMI shielding MXenes can be hybridized with MXene/silver nanowires in addition to cellulose nanofibers or copper nanowires/aramid nanofibers [216,217]. 6.2 Mxenes in energy storage and conversion MXenes have unparalleled potential in enhancing energy storage performance and enabling efficient energy conversion processes [218,219]. Their unique properties make them key contenders for the next-generation energy applications [38,220,221]. 6.2.1 Mxene-based supercapacitors MXene-based supercapacitors are attracting significant attention due to their exceptional electrochemical properties and high surface area, which arise from the unique structure and surface chemistry of MXene materials [222]. MXenes can be utilized as active materials in supercapacitor electrodes [223]. The design of the electrode architecture, such as porous structures or hierarchical frameworks, can enhance ion transport and increase the surface area for charge storage [224,225]. The increased abundance of surface functional groups in MXenes enhances their charge-storage mechanism, leading to superior energy storage capabilities [226,227]. The charge storage in MXenes can be broadly categorized into two types: electric double-layer capacitance (EDLC) and pseudocapacitance [228]. Pseudocapacitive mechanisms endow energy storage devices with much higher capacity than EDLC, as they undergo fast and reversible redox reactions on their surfaces, enhancing energy storage capabilities [163]. This makes pseudocapacitors ideal for efficient and powerful energy storage solutions. MXenes are typically used as negative electrodes due to their susceptibility to oxidation at positive potentials, requiring a complementary positive electrode for their usage in asymmetric devices [229,230]. Li et al. proposed a polyaniline@MXene cathode, formed by applying a uniform polyaniline layer at a porous 3D MXene (Ti3C2T x ) [231]. This structure enhances MXene stability at positive potentials, credited to the increased work function resulting from the polyaniline composite. The distinctive structure of MXenes makes them highly appealing for energy storage applications due to three primary reasons. Firstly, their inner conductive transition metal carbide layer facilitates rapid electron delivery to electrochemically active sites. Secondly, the transition metal oxide-like surface, formed during synthesis, exhibits redox activity, enhancing the charge storage capabilities. Finally, 2D morphology of MXenes and pre-intercalated water promote swift ion transport, further contributing to their superior performance as energy storage materials [75] (Fig. 11 a). In MXene-based supercapacitors, ion transport can be improved through different strategies, including interlayer intercalation and improving the porosity of the electrodes, etc. Intercalation can be utilized to increase the interlayer spacing between MXene flakes, enhancing the accessibility of electrolyte ions to the active sites, resulting in improved ion diffusion and charge storage capabilities [232–236]. Second, by designing nanoarchitectures with film porosity, additional ion diffusion pathways are created, facilitating faster and more efficient ion transport within the MXene electrode [232,237]. These approaches aim to optimize ion transport and enhance energy storage performance, making MXene-based supercapacitors more efficient and practical for various applications. The vertical alignment of 2D flakes facilitates directional ion transport, resulting in thickness-independent electrochemical performance in thick films. However, utilizing vertically aligned Ti3C2T x films demonstrate the electrochemical energy storage that remains independent of the film thickness even >200 μm thickness [232]. The tendency of a few atomic-thick MXene nanosheets to undergo layer-by-layer self-stacking is influenced by the strong van der Waals interaction between the sheets. Consequently, this self-stacking leads to the formation of significant “dead volume”, which reduces the effective active surface area available for ion storage and hinders efficient ionic transport pathways [237]. The ion transport can be facilitated via the vertical alignment of the MXene sheets as compared to the conventional horizontal alignment, as vertical alignment offers easy transport as demonstrated in Fig. 11(b and c). The optimized integration of three calcination-based methods, including carbonizing in situ grown polymer, alkali treatment, and template sacrificing, enables the fabrication of highly improved self-supporting, binder-free, and flexible Ti3C2T x MXene-based electrodes [238]. The achieved enhancements in capacitance, rate capability, and cyclic stability result from engineered electrode structure and surface chemistry modifications. Due to its bilayered structure, V2O5·nH2O presents advantages, including high capacity due to the high oxidation state of vanadium and its capability to undergo multiple reduction steps, open 2D channels facilitating the ion diffusions, etc., so it can be effectively combined with MXenes to enhance the energy storage capacity in supercapacitors [239,240]. Besides these, electrochemical capacitor devices based on textiles, featuring a high areal loading of Ti3C2T x , can be integrated in series using a stacked design approach, meeting the practical power needs for wearable electronics [241]. 6.2.2 MXenes applications in batteries MXenes can be used as electrode material for various types of metal-ions batteries [242]. MXenes use in lithium-ion batteries offers several advantages that contribute to improved battery performance. MXenes 2D morphology provides a large surface area for Li-ion adsorption and diffusion, enhancing the battery capacity to store and release Li-ions during charge–discharge cycles. Theoretical studies revealed that MXenes with low formula weights, such as Ti2C, Nb2C, V2C, and Sc2C, hold significant promise in terms of theoretical gravimetric capacity [243]. The gravimetric capacity, i.e., the charge stored per gram of the material, makes these specific MXenes particularly attractive for energy storage purposes. It means that M2X electrodes are anticipated to exhibit superior gravimetric capacities in comparison to their M3X2 and M4X3 counterparts. The robustness of the bonds between M and X atoms makes it reasonable to assume that ions can penetrate only between the MXene sheets [38]. This assumption was supported by the experimental comparison between Ti2C and Ti3C2, which share the same surface chemistry. It was revealed that Ti2C with the distinctive characteristic showcases an approximately 50% higher gravimetric capacitance when compared to Ti3C2. The reason behind this lies in the presence of one inactive TiC layer in Ti3C2. In an experimental observation, it was confirmed that the gravimetric capacity of Ti2CT x for Li+ uptake was found to be roughly 1.5 times greater than that of Ti3C2T x under similar synthesis conditions [244,245]. Using DFT computations, researchers investigated the electronic properties and Li storage capabilities of Ti3C2 MXene material. Li adsorption displays a strong coulomb interaction with the Ti3C2-based hosts, while preserving their structural integrity. The Ti3C2 monolayer in its pristine form showcases both excellent Li diffusion characteristics and a high capacity for Li storage. However, the presence of –F and –OH groups on the MXenes surface hinders the Li transport and decreases the Li storage capacity [131,139]. MXenes exhibit low initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) issues, which are attributed to the entrapment and irreversible reactions with Li ions. Guan et al. introduced a novel doping engineering approach to regulate the d-band center, enabling customizable surface chemistry in MXenes [246]. The applicability of this approach is confirmed across various MXenes, including V2− y Cr y C, TiNbC, and TiVC, underscoring its versatile nature. Besides Li-ion batteries, MXenes can be used in Li-sulfur and Li-sodium batteries [247–249]. MXene tethered with TiO2 can be used in Li-S batteries. The presence of TiO2 on MXene sheets serves as capturing centers, effectively immobilizing polysulfides (Fig. 12 a). The TiO2-MXene interface ensures the rapid diffusion of polysulfides from TiO2 to MXene. Additionally, the O-terminated MXene surface exhibits high catalytic activity for polysulfide conversion [250]. To create a functional separator, Ti3C2T x MXene debris was coated on the surface of a biodegradable eggshell membrane (ESM), resulting in the formation of MXene/ESM [251]. The uniform coating and even distribution of MXene debris on ESM create an additional physical barrier layer (Fig. 12b and c). The “acidic” Ti atom in MXene engages in a Ti-S Lewis acid-base interaction with polysulfide intermediates, leading to the chemical adsorption of soluble long-chain polysulfides. This interaction plays a crucial role in effectively suppressing the shuttle effect, thus contributing to the extended cycle life of Li-S batteries. Experimentally, to prepare Li-S Batteries based on MXenes, the delaminated MXenes (d-Ti3C2) were exfoliated from multilayered MXenes (m-Ti3C2) and filtered through polypropylene (PP) separator to prepare d-Ti3C2/PP. The alkalized Ti3C2T x (a-Ti3C2, prepared using KOH) was loaded by sulfur (S) using melting-diffusion process to prepare a-Ti3C2-S slurry which also contains carbon black and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) (Fig. 12d and e). The electrochemical performance of the integrated electrode comprising a-Ti3C2-S/d-Ti3C2/PP was evaluated for Li-S batteries within the voltage range of 1.6 to 3.0 V [252]. The d-Ti3C2 interlayer in the electrode prevents polysulfide shuttle effects. This yields an integrated electrode with a remarkable reversible capacity of 1062 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C and rate capacity of 288 mA h g−1 at 10 C. MXenes can also be used as a separator in suppressing the redox shuttle. The abundant surface functional groups of MXenes act as active sites capable of binding various species, proving to be effective in mitigating shuttle effects in the batteries involving in addition to the suppression of redox shuttling effects [253]. These interactions on the MXene surface help to stabilize and confine the active species, preventing their unwanted migration and resulting in improved battery performance and cycling stability. Shi et al. introduced an approach to inhibit I3 − shuttling in Li-O2 batteries by employing LiI as a redox mediator (RM) using MXene-modified separators. The combination of LiI and MXene-modified separators proved to be effective in mitigating the I3 − shuttling phenomenon, enhancing the performance and stability of Li-O2 batteries (Fig. 13 a). A MXene-modified separator can be created by applying a mixture of MXene nanosheets and bacterial cellulose (BC) nanofibrils onto a glass fiber (GF) separator using a simple vacuum-assisted filtration technique (Fig. 13b). Bacterial cellulose was chosen for two main purposes. (1) It acted as a reinforcing material and cross-linking agent. (2) It improved electrolyte penetration and established a 3D ionic pathway for efficient lithium-ion conduction. The physical interaction between the polar functional groups on the surfaces of MXene nanosheets and BC facilitated their self-assembly and cross-linking, resulting in a 3D hierarchical porous structure. Fig. 13(c) outlines the proposed shuttle-inhibition mechanism of the MXene-BC@GF separator. The hierarchical porous structure allowed for increased exposure of the surface functional groups on MXene nanosheets, creating numerous active sites capable of binding with diffusive I3− ions, effectively suppressing their shuttling. Simultaneously, the interconnected 3D channels facilitated rapid lithium-ion transport, ensuring swift electrochemical reactions at the cathode. As a result of this design, the Li-O2 cell exhibited a notably high discharge capacity of 7943 mA h g−1 and displayed stable cycling performance over 100 cycles, which was three times longer than the control sample. Multilayered Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets can be utilized to create Ti3C2T x -PP modified separators with the low mass loadings (0.016 mg cm−2) and low thickness (1.2 µm to 100 nm) [254]. The strong interaction between LiPS intermediates and Ti atoms, along with –OH groups on the separator surface, effectively suppressed LiPS shuttling. The Li-ion diffusion coefficient is found to be increased with reduced Ti3C2T x layers. A Ti3C2T x MXene-based free-standing paper, featuring a unique hierarchical structure, serves as an efficient cathode for sulfur hosting with exceptional electrochemical performance [255]. The hierarchical MXene provides abundant surface-active sites, effectively suppressing LiPS shuttling through a dual-play immobilization mechanism involving thiosulfate/polythionate redox conversion and Lewis acid-base interactions. Modified Ti3C2T x with Magnolol improves Li-S battery cathode performance by suppressing polysulfide shuttling [256]. The novel nucleophilic substitution strategy enhances the structure variety of MXenes. Modified Ti3C2T x -S electrode exhibits outstanding cyclic stability (0.041% capacity fading rate) and low fading rate (0.07%) even at high sulfur loading (7.2 mg cm−2). The unique chemisorption and catalytic conversion abilities of the electrode contribute to long-term cycling performance. With a porous network facilitating Li+ diffusion and lower energy barriers, Ti3C2T x -S displays excellent rate capability (535 mA h g−1 at 1 C) with 4 mg cm−2 S loading. Cobalt nanoparticles on MXene nanosheets (Co/Ti2C) serve as catalysts in lithium-sulfur batteries, enhancing sulfur utilization [257]. Through ex-situ electrochemical data, the catalytic process of Co/Ti2C is clarified, optimizing chemical adsorption, catalytic activity, and lithium-ion transfer. This optimization, involving electronic/ion modulation and sufficient interfaces, enhances overall electrochemical performance. The catalysis of Co/Ti2C anchors LiPSs, promotes redox reactions, and facilitates efficient sulfur conversion. Additionally, ion supplementation and chemical interaction with LiPSs enhance the conversion of long-chain to short-chain LiPSs. The multi-step catalysis accelerates consecutive solid-liquid-solid reactions, contributing to efficient sulfur transformation [257]. MXene (Ti3C2T x ) interlayer, with a TiS2/TiO2 heterostructure formed through vulcanization, acts as a sandwich structure [258]. TiO2 nanoparticles adsorb LiPSs, while TiS2 nanoparticles catalyze the conversion of long-chain LiPSs to short-chain Li2S2/Li2S within the high conductivity of Ti3C2T x . The interlayer also safeguards the lithium metal anode by preventing polysulfide deposition. The MXene interlayer demonstrates outstanding performance with stable long-term cycling. In a recent development, a flower-like MXene/MoS2/SnS@C heterostructure, with enhanced Li-S batteries, exhibits exceptional electrochemical performance, maintaining a capacity of 836.1 mA h g−1 over 200 cycles at 0.5 C [259]. The cycling stability remains remarkable, with a capacity attenuation of approximately 0.051% per cycle during 1000 cycles at 2 C. Even at a high sulfur loading of 5.1 mg cm−2, the capacity maintains 722.4 mA h g−1 over 50 cycles. In another study, loose templating of sulfur spheres was achieved using Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets adorned with polymorphic CoSe2 nanoparticles for Li-S batteries [260]. This approach prevents nanosheet aggregation, imparts a robust electrocatalytic effect, and results in enhanced reaction kinetics and battery performance. Additionally, MXenes can also be used in fabrication of binder free batteries [261]. The electrical conductivity of MXene ensures efficient electron transport during lithium-ion insertion and extraction, leading to faster charging and discharging rates. The surface terminations and functional groups of MXenes can be tailored to optimize lithium-ion intercalation, further enhancing the battery's performance. Utilizing free-standing 3D macroporous MXenes films and Ti3C2T x hollow spheres enhances Na-ion battery performance, offering flexibility, high conductivity, and simplified electrode construction without the need for binders or current collectors [262]. The electrical and mechanical contacts in Na-ion batteries can be improved by synthesizing Bi2Se3/MXene/single walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNT) binder-free anode materials through vapor deposition [263]. This enhances surface area, improves expansion/contraction, and establishes mechanical and electrical contact resulting in enhanced performance. Ti2C MXene sheets, grown on carbon cloth through a molten salt method and selective etching, form a freestanding anode for Li-ions and Na-ions batteries [264]. The cross-linked carbon fibers provide conductivity, eliminating the need for additional electrode preparation and inert binders. MXenes can be integrated with an organic compound, cyano-substituted diquinoxalinophenazine (6CN-DQPZ), to create a self-supported, binder-free electrode (6CN-DQPZ@MXene) for K-ion batteries applications [265]. The introduction of cyano electron-withdrawing groups optimizes the electronic structure, enhancing electrochemical activity and providing additional redox-active sites for rapid, stable, and efficient aqueous K+ storage in the electrode, as demonstrated by theoretical calculations. The Na-ions and K-ions storage performance of the MXenes can be improved by introducing the carbon nanotubes (CNT) network [266]. A high-performance sodium- and potassium-ion storage anode, Ti3C2T x /CNT hybrid, was rationally fabricated through surfactant-free assembly with HCl assistance, leveraging nanoscale integration for optimal electrochemical properties. The high conductivity of CNT enhances electron and sodium/potassium ion diffusion paths, yielding exceptional electrochemical properties for both sodium and potassium-ion storage through synergistic effects with Ti3C2T x flakes. Hence, MXenes demonstrate versatile behavior in Li-ion, Na-ion, and K-ion batteries, offering enhanced performance through tailored designs, conductivity, and structural stability, showcasing their promising role in the advancement of next-generation energy storage technologies. 6.3 MXenes in hydrogen storage and fuel cells MXenes have garnered considerable attention for their potential applications in hydrogen storage and fuel cells due to their unique properties and tunable surface chemistry. 6.3.1 MXenes in hydrogen storage MXenes possess a large surface area, providing abundant adsorption sites for hydrogen molecules, facilitating their storage in the material [267] The tunable surface chemistry of MXenes allows for functionalization, creating favorable interactions with hydrogen molecules and improving their adsorption capacity. The 2D morphology of MXenes promotes efficient hydrogen diffusion within the material, contributing to rapid adsorption and desorption kinetics [268,269]. The stability and mechanical robustness of MXenes ensure the preservation of hydrogen storage properties over multiple adsorption–desorption cycles [270]. Ab initio molecular dynamic simulations have confirmed that under ambient conditions, the hydrogen molecules can be adsorbed and released reversibly, achieving a hydrogen storage capacity of 3.4 wt%. This interaction is attributed to the Kubas-type binding interaction [267]. For the investigation of hydrogen adsorption, a Ti2C 3 × 3 periodic supercell containing nine carbon and eighteen titanium atoms (Fig. 14 a) was utilized as the host material. To identify favorable adsorption sites, three types of high-symmetry sites were considered on Ti2C surfaces: the top site located over a Ti atom on the top surface, the hollow_1 site situated above the center of three Ti atoms on the top surface with one Ti atom present at the bottom surface, and the hollow_2 site positioned above the center of three Ti atoms on the top surface with one C atom present at the bottom surface. During the hydrogenation process, the initial batch of H2 molecules arriving on the clean surface of 2D Ti2C dissociates into H atoms, which then occupy the hollow_1 site. To represent this situation, another model labeled as Ti2C(3 × 3)_18H was also analyzed (Fig. 14b), where the H atoms are adsorbed on the hollow_1 sites on both sides of 2D Ti2C. Eq. (9) can be used to calculate the binding energy (E b) between the H2 molecules and MXene (Ti2C). (9) E b = E h o s t + nE H 2 - E h o s t + n H 2 / n In the equation, E h o s t , E H 2 , and E h o s t + n H 2 represent the total energy of the host structure, the total energy of a free H2 molecule, and the total energy of the host structure with the adsorption of hydrogen molecules, respectively. The variable “n” denotes the number of adsorbed hydrogen molecules. The calculated binding energy for this configuration is 5.027 eV per H atom, with an H–Ti distance of 1.977 Å. The significant binding energy indicates a strong chemisorption interaction between the dissociated hydrogen atoms and the Ti2C surface. It was found that the total hydrogen storage capacity was ∼8.6 wt%. In another study, hydrogen adsorption, dissociation, and diffusion on Ti2C MXene were investigated by first-principles calculations using DFT [271]. In this case, in Ti2C 3 × 3 × 1 supercells, three distinct adsorption sites, namely Ti top, hollow site A, and hollow site B, were considered, in addition to carbon vacancies (Fig. 14c). The side view of Ti2C 3 × 3 × 1 supercells, showing both end-on and side-on configurations, is shown in Fig. 14(d). The adsorption energy (E ads) of H2 molecules and H atoms was calculated using the following Eqs. (10) and (11) as given below. (10) E a d s = E T i 2 C + H 2 - E T i 2 C - E H 2 (11) E a d s = E T i 2 C + H - E T i 2 C - E H 2 / 2 where E(Ti2C + H2), E(Ti2C), and E(H2) represent the calculated total energy of the Ti2C supercell with H2 adsorbed, with or without a carbon vacancy, and H2 molecule, respectively. The calculation of adsorption energies for the H2 molecule included both end-on and side-on configurations. In the end-on configuration, the H–H bond lengths closely resembled those of the free H2 molecule, confirming the adsorption of hydrogen in its molecular form. These findings strongly support the physisorption of the H2 molecule on Ti2C MXene. On the other hand, in the side-on configuration, the H2 molecule underwent dissociation into H atoms. Various configuration models were proposed for the adsorption of dissociated H atoms, and it was observed that both H atoms preferably adsorb on hollow A site positions. Experimentally, the utilization of MXene as a catalyst has shown promise in enhancing the hydrogen storage properties of MgH2. This is achieved by preparing a self-assembled MXene-based catalyst through the deposition of Ni nanoparticles onto the surface of exfoliated Ti3C2 nanosheets (Ni@Ti3C2). The resulting hybrid catalyst facilitates improved hydrogen adsorption and desorption kinetics in MgH2, leading to enhanced hydrogen storage capacity and efficiency [272]. The analysis indicates that the 2D-Ni@Ti3C2 catalyst exhibits a hydrogen absorption capacity of 4 wt% at room temperature.
