This significant hydrogen uptake at ambient conditions highlights the promising potential of the MXene-based catalyst in enhancing hydrogen storage properties. The mechanism for hydrogen storage involves the formation of a distinctive core–shell nanostructured MgH2@Mg2NiH4 hybrid material, which is regarded as the key driving factor for enhancing the hydrogen sorption properties of MgH2 (Fig. 14e). The proposed mechanism for the rapid hydrogen absorption/desorption of MgH2 is facilitated by the multiphase interfaces in the MgH2 + Ni@Ti3C2 system. The excellent hydrogen sorption kinetics of the MgH2 + Ni@Ti3C2 composite at relatively low temperatures is attributed to the nanoscale features of the MgH2@Mg2NiH4 hybrid material, which provides large surface-to-volume ratios and shorter diffusion distances for hydrogen atoms. Additionally, the presence of nanostructured multiphase components in the system (Mg2Ni, TiO2, metallic Ti, or amorphous C) influences the interfaces with the primary hydriding phase, further enhancing the hydrogen sorption properties of MgH2. A simple oxidation-etching-oxidation strategy to enhance internal active sites in Ti3C2 MXene, leading to improved Mg-based hydrogen storage performance has been proposed [273]. Exposing and modifying internal edge Ti active sites, particularly those on the edge plane, which are more active than those on the basal plane, enhances the potential of cheese-like Ti3C2 for hydrogen storage. A facile method produces a Pt-loaded MXene catalyst for efficient dehydrogenation of aluminum hydride, maintaining high hydrogen storage capacity and offering a promising material modification approach [274]. The outstanding catalytic activity is attributed to Pt-nanoparticles confined in the Ti3C2 MXene layers, facilitating hydrogen transfer and utilizing the multivalent surface of MXenes for electron transfer. 6.3.2 MXenes in fuel cell applications MXenes exhibit excellent catalytic activity, particularly when modified with active catalytic sites, making them promising candidates for fuel cell catalyst support. The high electrical conductivity of MXenes enables efficient electron transport, contributing to enhanced fuel cell performance [275]. MXenes surface can be functionalized to enhance the interaction with fuel cell electrolytes and optimize ion transport within the electrodes. MXenes have attracted new interest as catalyst supports in fuel cells due to their high efficiency in ORR [276]. In the ORR on MXenes, O2 molecules undergo reduction by accepting electrons and protons. This reduction reaction results in the adsorption of oxygen on the surface of MXenes. The mechanism of ORR in MXenes involves the following process [275,277]. 1. O2 + e− + H+ → Adsorption on MXenes 2. Formation of oxygen-containing intermediates such as superoxide ions (O2 −·), peroxide ions (O2 2−·), and hydroperoxyl radicals (HO2·). 3. Electrons are transferred from the MXene surface to the adsorbed oxygen species, leading to the reduction of oxygen. The MXene material facilitates this electron transfer process. 4. The reduction of oxygen species eventually leads to the formation of water molecules (H₂O) as the final product. The process involves the adsorption of oxygen on the MXene surface, followed by a sequence of reduction steps leading to the formation of oxygen-containing intermediates. MXenes facilitate electron transfer, ultimately resulting in the reduction of oxygen and the production of water. However, the ORR efficiency depends upon the terminal groups present on the MXene surface. These surface terminations, which can include –OH, –O, –F, or other moieties, play a crucial role in facilitating the ORR on the MXenes [276]. According to Liu et al., the F-terminated surfaces exhibit superior performance for the ORR compared to the O-terminated counterparts. However, the F-terminated surfaces are expected to have lower stability compared to the O-terminated surfaces (Fig. 15 a). The less strongly bound F and the more negatively charged C layer in the Ti n +1C n F2 surface led to a higher extent of an overall electron transfer from the first C layer to the adsorbates. The slightly more negatively charged intermediate on the Pt/v-Ti n +1C n F2 (v represents the surface vacancy) surface might lead to a more facile reduction reaction (Fig. 15b). Cerium oxide (CeO2) is highly regarded as an exceptional free radical facilitator due to its unique ability to efficiently promote the reduction of radicals into water while being recoverable. Combining it with MXene can fabricate more effective fuel cells. The MXene-CeO2 hybrid can be synthesized through a self-assembly-cooperating in situ growth process, where CeO2 ultrafine nanoparticles were formed on the surface of electronegative ultrathin MXene nanosheets while using Nafion as proton exchange membranes (Fig. 15c). This hybrid material holds great promise for fuel applications [278]. The hybrid membrane with precisely controlled loading of MXene-CeO2 exhibited enhanced water uptake, proton conductivity, and output power. This improvement can be attributed to the enriched –OH groups and the high specific surface area of MXene-CeO2 nanosheets, which induced the configuration of –SO3H in Nafion near the nanosheet interface, thereby forming hydrophilic domains for water storage and efficient proton transfer. Additionally, MXenes in combination with CNTs can serve as a hybrid-supported platinum catalyst for achieving high-performance oxygen reduction reactions in proton exchange membrane fuel cells [279]. Novel MXenes include a tungsten nitride (W2N)-MXene composite catalyst for microbial fuel cells in domestic wastewater treatment [280] and Fe3C2 MXene obtained from iron-based MAX phase compound Fe3AlC2 etched solvothermally, where Fe-MXene nanosheets are adorned with Ni-nanopebbles through a simple electrodeposition method [281]. The Ni-nanopebbles exhibit excellent electrocatalytic activity with multiple oxidation states (Ni2+/Ni3+) and catalytic active sites, enhancing alcohol oxidation, while the metallic sites of Fe3C2 nanosheets add to electrode high stability and electrical conductivity. 6.4 MXenes applications in electronics MXenes have emerged as highly promising materials for applications in electronics and optoelectronics, thanks to their unique properties and versatile surface chemistry, high electrical conductivity and low resistance make them ideal for many electronics applications [282]. Their tunable electronic properties, modifiable through surface chemistry, enable their integration into various electronic components. Their tunable band gap allows for the design of light-emitting or light-harvesting devices with specific properties, while their photoluminescence capability facilitates the development of light-emitting devices [283]. 6.4.1 MXenes in sensors and flexible electronics MXenes possess a wide range of properties that render them highly suitable candidates for sensors, flexible transparent conductive electrodes (TCEs), and other optoelectronic devices fabrication. These attributes include high flexibility, hydrophilicity, exceptional transparency, high electrical conductivity, and a diverse surface chemistry [49,284]. In the realm of sensors, MXenes offer various advantages, including high surface reactivity and the ability to selectively functionalize their surfaces for specific analytes. This enables MXenes to be tailored for gas sensors, chemical sensors, and biosensors, among others [203]. MXene-based sensors have demonstrated remarkable sensitivity and selectivity in detecting gases, volatile organic compounds, and biomolecules [285]. The compatibility of MXenes with flexible and transparent substrates further broadens their application potential, enabling the development of wearable sensors and integrated sensing platforms. MXene can be combined with graphene oxide (GO) to prepare an aerogel using gas foaming technique, designed to maximize electron channels for a self-healable flexible pressure sensors application [77] (Fig. 16 a). The interlayer network of the MXene/rGO aerogel offers various electron channels during the application of pressure. MXene paper-based interdigital electrodes were fabricated using laser engraving. Following that, a layer of poly(ether imide) (PEI) fibers was electrospun onto the surfaces of the interdigital electrodes, serving as a separator (Fig. 16b). These components were then assembled together using self-healing polyurethane (PU) to create a self-healing flexible pressure sensor, as illustrated in Fig. 16(c). Fig. 16(d–l) showcases the practical applications of the MXene/rGO aerogel sensor, which include the identification of various bending angles for finger bending, wrist bending, elbow bending, knee bending, ankle bending, fast finger tap, pulse detection, 1 × 1 cm2 paper weight (5 Pa), air blow, etc. Additionally, MXene hybrids along with carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and cellulose nanofibers (CNFs) can be used in bioinspired e-skin applications [286]. CNTs, CNFs, and Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets are mixed and filtered to create the CCM film. A sticky substrate was fabricated by precuring silicone and pigment with the help of a polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) mold. Subsequently, the CCM film was transferred onto the silicone and pigment substrate and further encapsulated to form a flexible and user-interactive CCM e-skin. The CCM layer acted as the strain sensing and Joule heating layer, while the silicone and pigment substrate served as the thermochromic component and encapsulation layer. As a result, the CCM e-skin enabled digital-visual fusion for intelligent monitoring of human motions (Fig. 16m). Transparent and conductive Ti3C2T x films can also be applied as flexible transparent solid-state supercapacitors [287]. To prepare transparent flexible electrodes, MXene is spin-casted onto a PET substrate. To construct the supercapacitor, a layer of silver paint was coated on one edge of the Ti3C2T x film, followed by the application of nail polish (as a protective barrier) and gel electrolyte. The symmetric supercapacitors are prepared by sandwiching gel electrolyte between the Ti3C2T x films (Fig. 16n). The resulting supercapacitors demonstrated excellent transparency, flexibility, and conductivity, highlighting their potential for use in transparent and flexible energy storage devices with digital visual integration capabilities. MXenes have been extensively investigated for their applications in flexible TCEs, and the results have been promising [49,288,289]. MXene-based TCEs have demonstrated high transmittance levels, reaching approximately 87%, and exhibited a sheet resistance (R s) of 201 Ω sq−1. These remarkable properties position MXenes as superior to graphene when it comes to optoelectronic applications [287]. MXenes have exhibited significantly improved transmittance and sheet resistance values compared to TCEs based on single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs)/PEDOT and P3-SWCNTs [290,291]. Interestingly, Ti3C2T x MXene based TCEs demonstrate a Merit (FoM) value of >15, surpassing the FoM value of numerous other materials-based TCEs, except PEDOT and AgNWs-based TCEs [292,293]. Gogotsi and colleagues have pioneered in fabricating flexible TCEs based on Ti3C2T x MXene using spray coating or solution processing methods [49,85]. The Ti3C2T x MXene can be easily spray-coated on various substrates. The coated layered structure film having a thickness of ∼5 nm had a transmittance of ∼90%. Bending of the film to a 3.8 mm radius leads to a resistance change of ∼15% and after 10 bending cycles, the change was ∼25%, relatively poor to the TCEs based on other materials. Keep in mind that the ease of fabrication of MXene-based TCEs hints at a great promising future. In another report, Dillon et al. fabricated solution-processed MXene-based TCEs fabricated using a simple spin-coating technique. The TCEs have a σ DC/σ OP ratio ∼7.3, T = 86%, and R s = 330 Ω sq−1. Flexible films also exhibited just a 5% change when bent up to a 5 mm radius of curvature [49]. To prevent the oxidation of MXene in flexible TCEs, MXene can be combined with silver nanowires and polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) to make flexible transparent MXene/AgNWs/PVA electrode using a spray coating process followed by spin coating of PVA [294]. After hot pressing, the film can be peeled off (Fig. 16o). The fabricated film exhibited a transmittance variation from 74% to 44% and a sheet resistance ranging from 1649 to 4.4 Ω sq−1. Remarkably, the film demonstrated high robustness with negligible impact after 10-times tape peelings. During the inner and outer bending tests, up to 1000 bending cycles, the film experienced only a 5% change in resistance at a 2 mm bending radius of curvature. With their unique combination of high conductivity, chemical versatility, and large surface area, MXenes offer significant advantages for the development of sensitive and selective sensors. Ti3C2T x MXenes based sensors can effectively detect ethanol, methanol, acetone, and ammonia gases at room temperature [295]. The sensors exhibit the highest response to ammonia and the lowest to acetone, with a calculated limit of detection for acetone gas at approximately 9.27 ppm, showcasing superior performance compared to sensors based on other 2D materials. The sensors based on a 3D MXene framework fabricated through electrospinning and self-assembly demonstrate high sensitivity to low concentrations of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) at room temperature, attributed to its interconnected porous structure [296]. The sensor exhibits an ultra-wide sensing range, fast response and recovery, and excellent reversibility and flexibility for various VOCs, making it a promising candidate for gas sensing applications. Additionally, electrostatic self-assembly of CuO/Ti3C2T x MXene hybrids enables effective toluene detection [297]. These sensors display a significantly enhanced toluene gas sensing response (R g/R a) of 11.4 at 250 °C, nearly 5 times higher than pristine CuO nanoparticles (2.3) for 50 ppm of toluene. A glucose biosensor is developed with immobilized glucose oxidase on an Au/MXene nanocomposite, displaying a linear response (0.1 to 18 mM) and high sensitivity (4.2 μA mM−1 cm−2), with a detection limit of 5.9 μM [298]. Exhibiting an outstanding sensitivity with a low limit of detection (50–100 ppb) for volatile organic compounds at room temperature, MXene-based sensors showcase superior performance in gas sensing [299]. Recently, a chemiresistive gas sensor utilizing V2O5 and V2CT x MXene (V2C/V2O5 MXene) was reported. This sensor, designed for gas sensing applications at room temperature, also demonstrates excellent performance in detecting acetone [300]. Recently, partly oxidized Nb2CT x MXene, functionalized with plasmonic elements, has been employed for room temperature ammonia sensing through the localized surface plasmon resonance (also known as LSPR) effect [301]. The oxidized Nb2CT x MXene functions both as NH3 adsorption sites and conductive layers on flexible PET substrates, facilitating significant charge transfer. These findings were also supported by using DFT calculations. For comparison, HF-Nb2CT x MXene is synthesized through HF chemical etching, and HT-Nb2CT x is prepared via LiF/HCl etching using a hydrothermal process. Subsequently, Au nanorods coated with CTAB are attached to the negatively charged surfaces of HT-Nb2CT x MXenes to create Au/HT-Nb2CT x through electrostatic interaction. Fig. 17 (a) depicts the gas sensor structure with a flexible PET substrate, Au signal electrode, and sensing materials. Sensitivity to 100 ppm NH3 for various Nb-based gas sensors is illustrated in Fig. 17(b), where sensitivity (S) is the ratio of the relative change in electrical resistance (ΔR) to the baseline resistance (R 0). The sensitivity of the fabricated sensors during bending at different angles (α = 15°, 30°, 45°, and 60°) is illustrated in Fig. 17(c). The inset provides the bending direction and images of the flexible device under mechanical strain. The sensitivity remains consistently stable at various angles, maintaining approximately 95% of its initial sensitivity. Furthermore, Fig. 17(d) demonstrates the exceptional long-term stability of the sensor, with sensitivities measured every five days showing consistent performance over 30 days. Recently, MXenes enabled the creation of skin-like sensors to precisely detect temperature and pressure stimuli without any interference [302]. These sensors, utilizing MXene sheets on elastic and porous substrates, integrate thermoelectric and conductive properties with thermal insulation, elasticity, and porosity. The result is a sensor with an ultralow temperature detection limit (0.05 K), high signal-to-noise ratio, and robust cycling stability. Additionally, the sensor demonstrates remarkable features for pressure detection, including high sensitivity, rapid response times, and exceptional durability. Additionally, Multifunctional flexible sensors fabricated using tannic acid-modified MXene-polyurethane film, inspired by human skin's asymmetric structure, is proposed with a bionic Janus architecture [303]. Prepared through gravity-driven self-assembly, the fabricated film exhibits strong mechanical properties, including superior elongation at a break and an ultimate tensile strength, along with self-healing performance. The remarkable properties, ease of processing, and mechanical stability of MXenes make them highly attractive for a wide range of TCEs applications, offering significant potential for future advancements in flexible electronic devices and optoelectronics. 6.4.2 MXenes in spintronics applications The bandgap tunning and augmenting magnetic properties in MXenes hold the potential to facilitate their incorporation into device configurations well-suited for spintronics [304]. The capacity of MXenes to showcase either metallic or semiconducting behavior, contingent upon the transition metal and surface terminations, offers versatility in customizing materials to meet precise spintronics needs. Certain MXenes, like Cr2TiC2, exhibit inherent magnetism, creating opportunities for deployment in spin-based devices reliant on the precise control of spin states [305]. Cr2NO2, and Mn2CT2 (T = F, Cl, or OH), possess intrinsic half-metallic properties, making them crucial electrode materials for spintronic devices alongside traditional metal and semiconductor materials [306,307]. The inherent antiferromagnetic (AFM) nature of Ti3C2T x is anticipated, but the introduction of functional groups such as F, OH, and sulfur-based groups (–S2 and –SO3H) induces the emergence of a magnetic moment [308]. The remarkably rapid spin switching can be governed by the optically-induced inter-site spin transfer (OISTR) effect, establishing the theoretical robustness of optically manipulating the magnetic spin state in a 2D MXene magnet [309]. Double MXenes, like Cr2TiC2FCl, exhibit properties of a unique bipolar antiferromagnetic semiconductor (BAFS) as investigated via DFT calculations [305]. The material displays opposite spin directions in the valence and conduction bands around the Fermi level. Cr2TiC2FCl exhibits semiconducting characteristics in both spin up and spin-down states, with an indirect band gap of 0.91 eV (Fig. 18 b). The valence band maximum (VBM) and conduction band minimum (CBM) arise from opposite spin channels, defining Cr2TiC2FCl as a bipolar antiferromagnetic semiconductor (BAFS). Unlike the proposed bipolar magnetic semiconductor (BMS), Cr2TiC2FCl is ferromagnetic, allowing control of its spin-polarization direction with a gate voltage. The BAFS feature can be described by three energy gaps (Δ1, Δ2, and Δ3), where Δ1, the spin-flip gap, is small enough for practical bipolar semiconductor applications, and Δ2 and Δ3 ensure a substantial half-metallic gap (Fig. 18d). With values of 0.91, 0.31, and 0.27 eV for Δ1, Δ2, and Δ3, respectively, Cr2TiC2FCl meets the criteria of BMS, positioning it as a promising 2D material for antiferromagnetic spintronics applications. The novel BAFS materials, with their antiferromagnetic order and bipolar semiconducting character, hold promise for generating, manipulating, and detecting spin-polarized carriers in AF spintronics. Analogous to conventional semiconductor field-effect transistors (FET), the gate voltage can switch half-metallicity and control spin-polarized orientation. A brief demonstration of a typical BAFS-based AF spin FET in Fig. 18(e) involves electron and hole doping to shift the Fermi level into the VB or CB. Hole doping shifts the Fermi level into VB, resulting in a 100% spin-up polarized current, while electron doping achieves a 100% spin-down polarized current. Experimentally feasible electron and hole doping through gate voltage application allows for controlled spin-polarized orientation and enhanced conductivity in BAFS materials, showcasing their promise for AF spintronics. Fig. 18(a and c) illustrates the substantial impact of hole or electron doping on the band structure of Cr2TiC2FCl. Doping induces a shift in the Fermi level to distinct spin-polarized VBM and CBM regions, allowing tunable carrier spin orientation and a transition from BAFS to HFAF. Low-density electron doping transforms Cr2TiC2FCl from BMSAF to HMAF with spin-down polarization, while hole doping results in a spin-up polarized HMAF state. This enables facile realization of completely spin-polarized currents with tunable carrier spin orientation. Utilizing first principles studies, MXenes have demonstrated potential in designing spintronic magnetic tunnel junctions (MTJs) [310]. Sc2CHO MXene serves as half-metallic electrodes, while Sc2NHO functions as semiconductor-based scattering regions. These MTJs exhibit stable spin currents with perfect 100% polarizability, attributed to the single-channel conduction capability of half-metal Sc2CHO. Additionally, the electronic structure of Mn2NO2 MXene, a 2D half-metal, is harnessed for the design of an efficient giant magnetoresistive (GMR) device [311]. The Au/nMn2NO2/Au heterojunction maintains its half-metallic properties, achieving an ultra-high GMR of 1.15 × 1031% at low voltage. The excellent half-metallic characteristics and 2D structure of Mn2NO2 MXenes position it as an ideal energy-saving GMR material, showcasing the highest reported magnetoresistive ratio theoretically. 6.4.3 MXenes-based photodetectors MXenes have shown significant potential as promising materials for photodetectors due to their unique properties and versatile surface chemistry [312]. Their exceptional electrical conductivity and broadband light absorption properties make them suitable for photodetector applications across a wide range of wavelengths, including ultraviolet, visible, and infrared regions [312,313]. MXenes can be engineered to exhibit tunable band gaps, allowing for the design of photodetectors with specific photoresponse characteristics [313]. Additionally, their 2D morphology and high surface area facilitate efficient charge transport and interaction with incident photons, resulting in enhanced sensitivity and response speed. MXenes (Ti3C2T x ) can replace gold (Au) electrodes in GaAs photodetectors using a simple spin-coating technique [314]. The fabrication process, encompassing the production steps and the resultant devices, is elucidated in Fig. 19 (a), which also includes illustrations of energy band diagrams (Fig. 19c and d). Ti3C2T x obtained after etching Ti3AlC2 MAX phase is spin-coated on a GaAs substrate with a remarkable resolution of 2 µm (Fig. 19b). Energy band diagrams for the fabricated device are depicted in Fig. 19(c) (moderate bias) and Fig. 19(d) (large external bias). Utilizing transparent Ti3C2 MXene-based electrodes applied onto GaAs, these devices outperform standard Au electrodes, exhibiting higher responsivities, quantum efficiencies, and dynamic range, with comparable dark currents and sub-nanosecond response speeds. Besides Ti3C2T x , MoCT x MXenes exhibit a photoresponse with a resonant behavior in the visible region (500–800 nm) when exposed to supercontinuum white laser excitation [315]. This resonant behavior corresponds with the free carrier absorption window observed in the measured ultraviolet/visible/near-infrared (UV–vis-NIR) absorption spectrum of Mo2CT x . Fig. 19(e) illustrates the broadband visible photoresponse of the fabricated device, depicting a clear dependence of measured photocurrent on incident light power density. The linear I-V curves are indicative of an Ohmic contact with Au electrodes (Fig. 19f). The photocurrent-to-dark current ratios of the MXene photodetector across various light intensities indicate that the current gradually rises with increasing light intensity, attributed to an increased number of excited carriers, leading to a peak I on/I off ratio observed at specific light intensity and bias voltage conditions (Fig. 19g). Performance parameters, including photoresponsivity, specific detectivity, and EQE, decrease with increasing incident light intensity, attributed to trap state filling and enhanced recombination of hot carriers (Fig. 19h and i). A comparison of I on/I off current ratios under visible light illumination (532 and 660 nm) for photodetectors based on different MXene nanosheets (Fig. 19j) indicates Mo2CT x as the top performer. In the pursuit of enhanced plasmonic photodetector performance, particularly for broadband photodetection in devices relying on hot electrons, the introduction of photoactive materials with high mobility is crucial. Utilizing MoS2 and Mo2C interface properties, a highly sensitive and broad-spectrum photodetector can be fabricated [316]. The efficient injection of hot carriers from metallic p-Mo2C to MoS2, facilitated by a grating structure, leads to a low Schottky barrier height (∼70 meV) and three orders of magnitude improvement in photocurrent and responsivity compared to MoS2 photodetectors. Tuning the grating period (400 to 1000 nm) optimizes photoresponse across visible to NIR wavelengths. This adaptable approach yields a novel photodetector with broad-spectral range detection and exceptional sensitivity. In addition to these investigations, the photoreactivity of partially oxidized Ti3C2 MXene (TiO2-Ti3C2T x) thin films is explored, particularly focusing on the ultraviolet region [317] (Fig. 20 a). During the experimental procedure, the sample was exposed to ambient air with a humidity level of 20%–30%. Consequently, the resistance of the sample exhibited a gradual yet noteworthy increase over time. Under controlled conditions with continuous Ar flow, a freshly prepared Ti3C2T x thin film sample was exposed to UV irradiation. Upon turning on the UV lamp, a rapid and significant increase in current through the sample was observed, reaching saturation at approximately 12 μA (Fig. 20b). Switching off the UV lamp led to a gradual exponential decay of the current, while the rate of increase in photocurrent was approximately ten times higher than the decay rate. Repeatedly switching the UV lamp on and off resulted in consistent and reversible photoresponse of the MXene thin films within the Ar atmosphere. Notably, no measurable photocurrent was observed in response to visible light. Researchers also employed Ti3C2T x MXene as the electrode material and 2D CsPbBr3 as the active material to fabricate paper-based flexible photodetector arrays [318] (Fig. 20c). The interface between CsPbBr3 and Ti3C2T x exhibited a Schottky barrier due to the variation in their respective work functions. Upon exposure to incident light with higher energy than the bandgap of CsPbBr3, photogenerated electron-hole pairs were swiftly separated by the local electric field, resulting in enhanced conductivity (Fig. 20d and e). During the flexibility assessment, it was observed that with the gradual increase of bending angle, the photocurrent initially experienced a slight decrease but eventually stabilized (Fig. 20f). This behavior clearly highlights the outstanding stress release capability of these photodetectors, which can be attributed to the excellent laminated structure of both MXene and CsPbBr3 nanosheets. Relative to the initial state of the as-prepared devices, the dark current exhibited minimal change, and the photocurrent retained approximately 85% of its initial properties even after undergoing 1500 bending cycles (Fig. 20g). This clear evidence highlights the exceptional stability demonstrated by the as-prepared photodetectors. In another study, researchers fabricated a photodetector based on InSe and Ti2CT x electrode [76]. Fig. 20(h) illustrates the schematic representation of an InSe/Ti2CT x photodetector under light illumination. The time-resolved measurement results reveal a swift rising time (<2 ms) and a falling time of 25 ms (Fig. 20i). However, the response time of these photodetectors appears to be longer compared to photodetectors based on 2D InSe materials [319] due to the presence of imperfect material interfaces or traps, which may have originated from the transfer and patterning procedures involved in the fabrication process of the devices. A recent report introduces a high-performance ultraviolet photodetector featuring TiO2 nanorod arrays and Ti3C2T x MXene in a van der Waals Schottky junction [320]. The Ti3C2T x MXene, modulated by an Au electrode, forms a hole transport layer, suppressing Fermi-level pinning and enhancing the electric-field strength at the Schottky junction for improved charge separation and transport. Another study highlights a simple electrostatic assembly process to create a 2D/2D SnS2/MXene Nb2C heterostructure for high-performance photodetectors [321]. This combination enhances charge transfer, carrier density, and light absorption while reducing band bending and charge recombination, resulting in remarkable responsivity and ultrahigh specific detectivity. In summary, these studies demonstrate the promising role of MXenes in advancing photodetectors. MXenes showcase versatility and efficiency, marking them as valuable contributors to the evolution of advanced photodetection technologies. 6.5 MXenes for inks and 3D printing MXene inks are prepared by dispersing MXene nanosheets into a solvent, creating a printable solution that can be used for additive manufacturing processes like inkjet or screen printing. The preparation of MXene inks involves exfoliating MXene into nanoscale flakes after the MAX phase etching [95,322]. MXene-based filaments or inks can be used in 3D printing technique to fabricate complex and functional objects. The intrinsic hydrophilicity of MXene plays a pivotal role in its suitability for applications involving inks and 3D printing. This hydrophilic characteristic enables MXene to easily disperse in water-based solutions, forming stable colloidal inks [322]. This property is essential for the creation of uniform and printable MXene inks, providing the necessary foundation for producing intricate structures through various 3D printing techniques. The presence of diverse terminal groups on the MXene surface allows for compatibility with other solvents, enhancing flexibility in ink formulation [143]. The hydrophilic behavior is instrumental in preparing MXene-based inks with optimal rheological properties, ensuring a seamless and controlled deposition process during 3D printing. The excellent mechanical properties of MXenes, such as high strength and flexibility, enhance the structural integrity and durability of the printed parts. MXenes can also be combined with other materials, such as polymers and ceramics, to create hybrid composites with improved performance and functionalities [323]. MXene inks can be easily processed into printable formulations compatible with various printing techniques, such as inkjet printing, screen printing, and aerosol jet printing [322]. The ability to print conductive patterns directly onto flexible substrates enables the rapid and cost-effective production of electronic circuits, sensors, and antennas [324–326]. The MXenes based organic inks were prepared from MXene aqueous dispersions using a centrifugation and resuspension process [322]. Various solvents such as N-Methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), DMSO, DMF, and ethanol were employed for ink formulation. The printing process involved substrate fixation, elevating substrate temperature and controlling ink ejection to achieve successful printing of precise patterns, resistors, and micro-supercapacitors on different substrates (Fig. 21 a). Divalent cations (Zn2+) aided gelation process is useful in preparing 3D printing MXene-based inks used in supercapacitors [327]. To prepare the inks, MXene supernatant is obtained after centrifugation, and a solution containing ZnSO4·7H2O is introduced into the MXene suspension. The resulting MXene ink is loaded into a syringe with a metal needle for constructing a 3D structure using 3D programming software. To maintain the structure, a freeze-drying process is applied after printing (Fig. 21b). The direct ink writing (DIW) method is utilized for crafting MXene-based frames with customizable architecture for EMI shielding applications [328]. AlOOH nanoparticles are incorporated into the MXene ink to manage flowability, ensuring printability and structural robustness. The MXene/AlOOH (MA) filaments are printed layer by layer, forming an internally connected 3D conductive frame (Fig. 21c). Post freeze-drying and hydrochloric acid etching eliminate insulating AlOOH nanoparticles, resulting in a gelled MXene frame (MG) with notable electrical conductivity and high EMI shielding effectiveness in the X-band. This MXene ink facilitates the creation of diverse structures, including MG cubic frames and “woodpile” microlattices (Fig. 21d), double split rings (Fig. 21e), and EMI shields (Fig. 21f) for electronic devices. Furthermore, direct ink printing generates adaptive hemisphere frameworks (Fig. 21g), showcasing the versatility of MXene-based applications. MXene inks-based 3D printed structures are used in supercapacitors and as electrodes in EMI shielding [329,330]. In addition to 3D printing, MXenes are employed in four-dimensional (4D) printing technology to produce hydrogels with customizable geometries and actuating structures [331,332]. These MXene hydrogels exhibit 3D porous structures, significant specific surface areas, impressive electrical conductivities, and robust mechanical properties, catering to various MXenes, like Ti3C2T x , Nb2CT x , and Mo2Ti2C3T x . 6.6 MXenes for environmental applications These 2D transition metal carbides and carbonitrides offer excellent electrical conductivity, tunable surface functional groups, and high surface area, making them highly attractive for various environmental challenges [333]. MXenes offer promise in tackling environmental issues, serving as efficient adsorbents for pollutant removal in water and other environmental matrices [68,334]. Their high surface area and tunable surface functional groups enable strong interactions with various pollutants, including heavy metals, organic compounds, and dyes [335]. 6.6.1 Photocatalytic applications of MXenes MXenes have recently emerged as promising candidates for photocatalytic applications due to their unique properties and surface chemistry. Their exceptional light absorption ability across a broad spectrum, including ultraviolet, visible, and near-infrared regions, makes them highly efficient photocatalysts. The high surface areas of MXenes provide abundant active sites for photocatalytic reactions, enhancing the interaction with target molecules and promoting catalytic efficiency [336–339]. Moreover, the tunable surface functional groups of MXenes enable selective adsorption and activation of specific reactants, allowing for the design of tailored photocatalysts for various applications. MXenes undergo photocatalysis through a light-driven process where electron-hole (e −-h +) pairs are generated [340]. Electrons move to MXenes trap sites (ē), forming reactive species with oxygen. Holes contribute to the creation of hydrogen ions (H+) and hydroxyl radicals (OH·). These reactive species then engage in pollutant degradation (CR), producing CO2, H2O, and byproducts. The mechanism of photocatalysis in MXenes involves following process presented by Eqs. (12)–(17) [341]. (12) MXene + hv → (e −-h +) pairs (13) MXene + e − → ē (trap sites) (14) e - ( t r a p s i t e s ) + O 2 → O · 2 - (15) h + + H2O → H++ OH (16) CR + OH·→ CO2 + H2O + byproducts (17) C R + O · 2 - → C O 2 + H 2 O + b y p r o d u c t s An efficient photocatalytic ensemble for visible-light-driven CO2 reduction is being created as cobalt atoms are anchored onto Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets [338]. These nanosheets effectively bridge visible-light absorbers (ruthenium complex) with cobalt active sites. The cobalt atoms establish robust interactions with MXene, forming metal–oxygen/carbon bonds, resulting in the formation of the Co-Ti3C2T x ensemble (Fig. 22 a). Consequently, the optimal Co-Ti3C2T x configuration is achieving a remarkably high CO production rate of 6.06 mmol h−1 g−1. MXene based photocatalysts can be used for solar energy conversion [342]. The 2D structure of MXene offers abundant surface groups, facilitating strong connections with other 2D photocatalysts to establish 2D/2D heterojunctions (Fig. 22b). These MXene-based heterojunctions exhibit close face-to-face contact, greatly enhancing the separation and migration of photoinduced charge carriers across the interface. Photoinduced electrons from 2D photocatalysts become localized on the MXene surface due to its suitable Fermi level and exceptional electronic conductivity. MXene serves as an electron mediator, intensifying interlayer interactions in face-to-face heterostructures, thus expediting electron extraction from 2D photocatalysts for enhanced photocatalytic reactions. MXene-black phosphorus (BP) hybrids, leading to the formation of Ti3C2T x /TiO2-BP nanohybrids synthesized using a hydrothermal method, wherein TiO2 is formed during the hydrothermal process, are effective in photocatalytic applications [343]. This formation of TiO2 accelerates electron transfer and augments the availability of active sites. The better photocatalytic performance is attributed to the synergistic interplay of BP and Ti3C2T x /TiO2, which substantially enhances BP stability, boosts visible light absorption, extends photoexcited electron lifetimes, expedites photoinduced electron transfers, and impedes electron-hole (e −-h +) pair recombination. ·O2 − radicals play a pivotal role in steering the photocatalytic process. Under visible-light illumination, photoexcited electrons shift from valance band (VB) of BP to conduction band (CB). Subsequently, CB electrons from BP move to CB of TiO2 via the ultrathin layered heterojunction due to more negative potential (−0.45 V vs. SHE) of TiO2. This leads to electron migration to Ti3C2T x due to its lower E F, creating a depletion layer at the semiconductor/metal interface due to the different E F of TiO2 and Ti3C2T x . Schottky-junction formation between upward-bending energy bands of Ti3C2T x and TiO2 inhibits electron back-diffusion. Photoexcited electrons in BP also migrate to Ti3C2T x , rapidly reaching its surface thanks to its high conductivity, eventually forming ·O2 − via electron capture by O2 at the plane of Ti3C2T x . This radical can be further reduced to produce ·OH, which ultimately degrades contaminants into CO2, H2O, or other byproducts along with strong oxidizing radicals (Fig. 22c). Recent studies explored MXenes photocatalytic properties, achieving nearly 100% effectiveness in decomposing model dyes. MILD technique (LiF/HCl) etched MXenes outperformed HF/TMAOH etched MXenes, requiring seconds for dye decomposition, and both MXenes retained about 70% activity [344]. Additionally, a novel 2D/2D CdS nanosheets@Ti3C2-based composite demonstrated enhanced photocatalytic performance due to increased surface area and improved charge separation [345]. Computational investigations on Cr2CT2 MXenes (T = F, Cl, H, and OH) for water-splitting applications revealed tunable band gaps and favorable electronic properties [346]. Functionalized MXenes exhibit visible-range band gaps suitable for water-splitting reactions. Some also show an indirect band gap, beneficial for spatial charge pair separation and migration. 6.6.2 MXenes in water purification and remediation processes MXene materials have shown great promise in water purification and remediation processes due to their high surface area and tunable surface functional groups enabling strong interactions with a wide range of contaminants, including heavy metals, organic pollutants, and dyes. The ability of MXenes to selectively adsorb specific pollutants makes them efficient and effective adsorbents for water treatment. The distinctive features of MXene include an inherent negative surface charge (zeta potential of −29 mV at pH 7 [347]) along with a hydrophilic surface that exhibits a contact angle of approximately 25° [348]. These attributes collectively render it highly suitable for efficient ion separation in aqueous solutions. Moreover, MXene can find application in the selective sieving of ions based on both their charge and size using MXene membranes [349]. MXenes are currently being employed for the pressure-free removal of various negatively and positively charged heavy metal ions (HMIs) from water [202]. The microstructure of Ti3C2T x MXene-based films is optimized through the introduction of reduced graphene oxide between layers. Simultaneously, the film surface is gradually hydroxylated to enhance the accessibility of Ti3C2T x , elevate film wettability, and amplify the effectiveness of adsorption and reduction of HMIs. To prepare MXene-based films for HMI removal, reduced graphene oxide (RGO) is utilized as a spacer to mitigate the restacking of Ti3C2T x nanosheets, consequently leading to improved spatial accessibility. Furthermore, a surface hydroxylation procedure is undertaken on Ti3C2T x to enhance HMI removal (Fig. 23 a). This is achieved by refining the wettability of Ti3C2T x -based films, ultimately enhancing the adsorption and reduction of HMIs. Zeta potential plots were utilized to confirm the coulombic interaction between MXene and RGO. Upon liquid-phase mixing of RGO and Ti3C2T x , the zeta potential exhibited a positive shift to −17.9 mV, in contrast to the zeta potential of Ti3C2T x (Fig. 23b). The filtered film, along with the corresponding schematic illustration, is presented in Fig. 23(c and d). The efficacy of this film arises from the introduction of RGO, which reduces restacking and enhances Ti3C2T x surface accessibility and the surface hydroxylation that improves wettability. The surface hydroxylation also facilitates the reductive removal of HMIs by augmenting both their adsorption and reduction processes. The MXene film efficiently removes various HMIs through redox reactions, transitioning from the oxidation state (Mox) to the reduction state (Mre) (Fig. 23e). High-performance forward osmosis (FO) membrane can be prepared by incorporating Ti3C2T x MXene within polyamide layers [350]. The fabrication process involves brush-coating MXene on nylon substrates, followed by interfacial polymerization (Fig. 23f). The resulting FO membrane showcases remarkable water permeability (31.8 L m−2h−1) and low specific salt flux (0.27 g L−1) employing a 2 mol L−1 NaCl as a draw solution. The MXene-interlayered FO membrane exhibits outstanding performance in organic solvent forward osmosis, boasting high ethanol flux (9.5 L m−2h−1) and low specific salt flux (0.4 g L−1) with a 2 mol L−1 LiCl draw solution. Moreover, this membrane demonstrates feasibility in real seawater desalination and industrial textile wastewater treatment applications. For ion sieving, a hybrid SA-Ti3C2T x membrane, which possesses a lamellar structure, can be prepared by mixing a sodium alginate (SA) solution with diluted Ti3C2T x colloidal and then filtering it through a PVDF membrane [351]. Subsequently, the SA-Ti3C2T x membrane is being immersed in various multivalent Mn+ cross-linking solutions for 4 h, resulting in a cross-linked membrane with hydrogel pillars within the interlayer spacing (Fig. 23g). Following drying at room temperature under vacuum, peeling from the PVDF support, and storage under vacuum, the flexible membrane with Ca-alginate pillars is displaying nanochannel diameters of 7.4 ± 0.2 Å. This configuration is yielding a membrane with exceptional permeation cutoff and remarkable sieving properties for various valent cations. The membrane holds considerable promise for acid recovery due to its remarkable H+/Fe2+ selectivity, making it highly useful for traditional ion-exchange membranes. Additionally, an ultrathin Mn-alginate pillared membrane, with the same d-spacing, is exhibiting 100% Na2SO4 rejection alongside high water permeance. Recent advancements in the use of MXenes for water filtration and purifications include creating efficient 3D macroporous foamy MXene using sacrificial templates, demonstrating superior light-to-heat conversion efficiency [352]. Another study introduces a layer-by-layer repair method for MXene lamellar membranes, resulting in regular nanochannels and high rejection rates (up to 99.8%) for various substances [353]. Utilizing MXenes, a distinctive superhydrophilic/underwater superoleophobic MXene (Ti3C2T x )-PAN dual-functional membrane is crafted to efficiently adsorb organic dyes and facilitate oil–water separation [354]. The intrinsic hydrophilicity and low oil droplet adherence of the membrane contribute to remarkable separation performance and anti-oil fouling properties with outstanding recyclability. 6.7 MXenes in biomedical applications MXenes have shown significant potential in biomedical and healthcare applications due to their unique properties and biocompatibility. Their 2D morphology and high surface area make them ideal candidates for drug delivery systems, where they can efficiently load and release therapeutic agents [355]. The electrical conductivity of MXenes allows for the development of bioelectronic devices for neural interfaces and biosensors [356,357]. Moreover, MXenes have demonstrated excellent antibacterial properties, making them promising candidates for antimicrobial coatings and wound dressings [81,358,359]. Their versatility, biocompatibility, and tunable properties offer exciting possibilities for innovative solutions in biomedical and healthcare fields, contributing to advancements in drug delivery, diagnostics, and regenerative medicine [154,360]. MXene displays significant antibacterial capabilities, marking a significant stride in combatting bacterial infections. These materials exhibit the capacity to hinder bacterial growth and viability through interactions at the cellular level. The antibacterial mechanisms of MXenes involve their ability to disrupt bacterial processes, leading to inhibited growth and viability [358] (Fig. 24 ). This disruption occurs at the cellular level, where MXenes can interact with bacterial membranes, impair essential metabolic pathways, and induce oxidative stress. MXenes exhibit the capability to serve as effective generators of reactive oxygen species (ROS) [361]. ROS are oxygen molecules with unpaired electrons, displaying strong chemical reactivity that enables them to eliminate bacteria and combat cancer cells effectively [362]. Through interactions with light or other stimuli, MXenes can induce ROS production, which plays a crucial role in damaging the cellular structures of bacteria. The utilization of MXenes to generate ROS via ultrasound has primarily found application in the field of cancer treatment [363–365]. MXenes can function as nanoscale thermal blades due to their exceptional ability to convert light into heat. When exposed to light, MXenes efficiently absorb and convert the energy into thermal energy, enabling precise localized heating. This unique attribute positions MXenes possess remarkable photothermal efficiency, making bacterial eradication feasible through photothermal processes upon exposure to light-a crucial component of MXenes biocidal mechanism [78,366,367]. Combining MXenes nanoknife-like attributes with their potent antibacterial capabilities offers a novel approach to combating bacterial infections. MXenes, with their sharp edges and antibacterial properties, hold potential as advanced tools for precise bacterial cell membrane disruption at the nanoscale [81,368]. Additionally, MXenes have demonstrated remarkable photothermal antibacterial capabilities, positioning them as promising candidates for various antibacterial applications [369–374]. They can efficiently convert light into heat, which can then be harnessed to eliminate bacterial pathogens. The antibacterial mechanisms of MXenes primarily revolve around their intrinsic photo-to-thermal characteristics, prominently featuring photothermal therapy alongside other photo-induced synergistic treatments [375]. The ability of MXenes to selectively target and eliminate bacteria via controlled light exposure makes these useful as rapid-response in vitro antibacterial agents, wound dressings that accelerate bacteria-infected wound healing, antibacterial fabrics, solar-driven water purification, etc. (Fig. 25 ). Besides these, MXenes have emerged as promising candidates for drug delivery systems [376–379]. Their 2D morphology and high surface area enable efficient loading and controlled release of therapeutic agents [380]. The biocompatibility and tunable surface chemistry of MXenes allow for surface functionalization, enhancing targeted drug delivery and improving biocompatibility [381]. MXene-based drug delivery systems hold great potential for advancing personalized medicine and improving the efficacy of various treatments, offering new possibilities for more effective and targeted drug delivery approaches. MXene-based bioimaging and diagnostic platforms hold great potential for advancing early disease detection, improving patient outcomes, and driving advancements in personalized medicine [382,383]. MXene have also found applications in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine due to their unique properties and biocompatibility [384,385]. MXenes can be incorporated into scaffolds and hydrogels to improve their mechanical properties, allowing for the design of biomimetic and mechanically robust structures for tissue regeneration [384,385]. 7 Challenges and opportunities in MXenes research The area of MXenes is poised for exciting developments across various scientific and technological fronts. The future of MXenes presents a landscape of both exciting opportunities and challenges. 7.1 Opportunities in MXenes research The versatility of MXenes combined with their tailored surface chemistry holds great promise for diverse applications, spanning from energy storage and catalysis to sensors and biomedical devices. 1. Suitable alternate to graphene: MXenes take the lead over graphene and other 2D materials, thanks to their straightforward synthesis, hydrophilicity, and a distinctive combination of high conductivity and transparency. 2. Easy synthesis methods: Synthesizing MXenes involves relatively easy and less expensive approaches as compared to other 2D materials. Exploring innovative synthesis methods enhances the scalability, efficiency, and environmental sustainability of MXene production. 3. Diverse applications: Fluorine-free MXene synthesis introduces terminations like –O, –OH, and –Cl, positively shaping surface chemistry and enhancing properties, such as improved energy storage and optimized electrochemical performance. These methods mitigate the drawbacks linked to traditional –F terminations, expanding the applications of MXenes. 4. Enriched surface chemistry and tailored functionalization: Enriching MXene surface chemistry with diverse functional groups enhances their compatibility, while tailored surface functionalization unlocks new properties and functionalities, expanding their applicability. 5. Real-world implementations: Exploring real-world applications of MXenes presents opportunities across various industries, such as energy, catalysis, sensing, and healthcare, etc. 6. Interdisciplinary collaboration: MXenes research offers opportunities for interdisciplinary collaboration, promoting teamwork among researchers from diverse fields to harness their expertise in collectively addressing the challenges associated with MXenes to promote their interdisciplinary applications. 7. Collaborative research: MXenes research provides opportunities for collaborative endeavors among researchers and institutions worldwide, facilitating the exchange of knowledge, collective problem-solving, and the promotion of sustainable practices in advancing MXenes research. 7.2 Challenges in MXenes research Advanced synthesis methods and enhanced surface functionalization techniques are expected to broaden the scope of MXenes properties, providing researchers with a richer palette of materials to explore. However, challenges such as scalable production methods, oxidation of MXenes under ambient conditions, tailoring the surface terminations, and the development of standardized protocols for MXene applications remain to be addressed. The main challenges in MXenes research include. 1. Hazardous etchants: MXenes are mostly synthesized using hazardous acids like HF posing a serious threat to the environment as well as the researchers' safety. However, usage of fluorine free approaches is currently the best suited alternate to mitigate these adverse effects. 2. Efficacy of fluorine-free MXenes synthesis methods: Development of novel fluorine-free approaches and improving their efficacy in MXene etching/synthesis are a major challenge in MXenes research. This challenge can be resolved by using hybrid approaches or fine-tuning of various parameters. However, this area needs more exploration. 3. MXenes oxidation under ambient conditions: The biggest hurdle in MXenes applications is their susceptibility to oxidation under ambient conditions. This issue can be resolved by storing MXenes in airtight and humid-free environments. Surface passivation is another alternative to preserve MXenes against oxidation. Storing MXenes under low temperatures is another alternative. 4. Scalable production: Achieving large-scale production of MXenes to meet industrial demands while maintaining quality and consistency remains a significant challenge. As of now, very few facilities worldwide have the capability to produce MXenes on a scale of kilograms. Scalability of MXenes productions can be enhanced by optimizing production processes, employing efficient synthesis methods. 5. Tailoring surface terminations: Developing precise control over surface terminations to optimize specific properties for different applications poses a challenge, requiring advancements in synthesis techniques. Tailoring surface terminations of MXenes can be achieved through careful control of etching conditions and optimization of surface functionalization techniques. 6. Standardized protocols: MXenes research needs standardized protocols to ensure consistent and comparable results across studies. Establishing standardized protocols for the synthesis, functionalization, and application of MXenes is essential for ensuring reproducibility and comparability across research studies. The continued interdisciplinary efforts in MXenes research will likely unlock new dimensions of their potential, paving the way for innovative solutions across scientific and industrial domains. 8 Future prospects in MXene research The future prospects of MXenes research hold significant promise across various scientific and technological domains. Key areas of potential advancement include 1. Development of fluorine-free MXenes: Fluorine-free MXene etching strategies enhance electrical conductivity, electrochemical performance, etc. for superior applications in electronics, energy storage, catalysis, etc. Development of fluorine-free MXenes will not only provide hazardous free MXenes synthesis strategies, but also alter the MXenes properties positively. 2. Advanced computational methods: The use of computational methods in MXene research is vital for understanding their atomic-scale behavior, predicting, and optimizing properties, and accelerating materials discovery. These methods, such as DFT, molecular dynamics, Monte Carlo simulations, machine learning, and advanced quantum mechanical calculations, play a crucial role in elucidating MXene properties, guiding design, and expediting the development of tailored materials for diverse applications. 3. Life-cycle assessment (LCA) of MXenes: LCA of MXenes is necessary for their feasibility in future research and development. It involves considering various processes starting from selecting the appropriate MAX phase and selection of etching methods, etching environmental impacts from extraction to disposal. Hazardous acids in synthesis, like HF, pose risks, which can be mitigated by following safety measures and using eco-friendly etching methods. MXenes storage in controlled conditions and utilization of oxidized MXene in various applications open alternative avenues. Bulk synthesis (kg-MXenes) proves more efficient and eco-friendly, and cost effective as compared to small quantities synthesis. To enhance sustainability, recycling titanium and exploring greener metal sources are crucial [386]. Addressing environmental concerns involves recycling titanium and exploring ecologically benign metal sources, suggesting potential pathways for sustainable MXene synthesis. 4. Techno-economic studies for MXenes: Techno-economic studies for MXenes evaluate the economic feasibility of large-scale production, synthesis costs, market demand for MXenes, and potential revenues. These studies inform stakeholders involved in MXenes research and production about scaling challenges, regulatory compliance, and sustainability, aiding in strategic decision-making for industrial implementation of MXenes. 5. Avenues for future nanoelectronics: Exploring the combination of metallic, semiconducting, and magnetic properties in MXenes presents compelling avenues for future nanoelectronics/spintronics. 6. Collaborative efforts: Interdisciplinary collaborations among materials scientists, chemists, environmental experts, engineers, and industrialists create synergies, fostering innovative approaches, novel materials, and breakthroughs in MXene technology. 7. Flexible and transparent future devices: MXenes offer a unique combination of high conductivity and transparency, making them ideal for applications in wearable technology, flexible displays, and smart windows. Their inherent flexibility positions MXenes as a key player in advancing the next generation of electronic devices. 9 Conclusions and outlook In conclusion, this comprehensive review provides a thorough examination of MXenes, shedding light on their structural characteristics, synthesis methods, and the profound impact of surface functional groups. The diverse range of synthesis techniques, whether fluorine-based or fluorine-free, significantly influences the emergence of functional groups (–F, –O, –OH, –Cl, etc.) on MXene surfaces. These functional groups play a pivotal role in dictating the properties of MXenes, encompassing electrical conductivity, electronic properties, catalytic activity, magnetic properties, mechanical strength, and chemical and thermal stability. Undoubtedly, fluorine-based etching techniques exhibit high selectivity in the etching of MXenes. However, owing to concerns related to toxicity, safety, and environmental impact, there is a pressing need for alternative approaches. This imperative has led to the development of fluorine-free methods, prioritizing safety and minimizing environmental impact while facilitating the emergence of various terminal groups. Nevertheless, it is essential to recognize that each alternative approach comes with its own set of advantages and disadvantages. The review underscores the versatility of MXenes and their potential across a myriad of applications. From energy storage solutions such as supercapacitors and batteries to advanced technologies like EMI shielding and flexible electronics, MXenes exhibit promising characteristics in each application. Moreover, their applicability extends to environmental applications, including pollutant removal and water purification, as well as catalysis, biomedical, and healthcare fields. This holistic exploration highlights the multifaceted nature of MXenes, positioning them as key players in the landscape of advanced materials with wide-ranging applications. MXene research encounters hurdles relating to scalability, the stability of oxidation under ambient conditions, and toxicity concerns arising during synthesis, there are alternative approaches to mitigate these adverse effects. The future holds immense promise as ongoing research aims to address these hurdles. Leveraging DFT analysis and other theoretical studies is crucial for advancing the field of MXenes, as these computational techniques play a pivotal role in shaping the development of novel MXenes and understanding their properties. MXenes' high surface area and conductivity contribute to improved performance in batteries and supercapacitors, addressing the growing demand for efficient energy solutions. Moreover, MXenes' biocompatibility and tunable surface chemistry position them as potential candidates for innovative applications in medicine, such as drug delivery systems and biomedical imaging. The versatility of MXenes is expected to play a pivotal role in shaping technological landscapes and fostering innovation across these vital fields in the years ahead. We believe that this review, encompassing the fundamental aspects, synthesis techniques, functionalization, properties, and diverse applications of MXenes, can serve as a valuable resource for researchers, offering insights and guidance in the dynamic field of MXenes research. Sunil Kumar received his B.S. and M.S. degrees in Physics from Panjab University, Chandigarh, India in 2003 and 2008, respectively. He completed his Ph.D. at Thapar University, Patiala, India in 2016. In 2017, he joined Sejong University, Seoul, South Korea, as a postdoctoral fellow. Since 2022, he has been working as an Assistant Professor at Sejong University in the Department of Nanotechnology and Materials Engineering. His current research interests include MXene based smart windows, flexible transparent conductive electrodes, and energy storage devices. Nitu Kumari received her B.S. degree in Science (Bio) from Himachal Pradesh University, Shimla, India, in 2008, and an M.S. degree in Chemistry from Jiwaji University, Gwalior, India, in 2011. She has worked as a Science teacher in various schools and has shown a high interest in research. She is an aspiring research assistant with a focus on biomedical and environmental sciences. Her current research interests revolve around the development of nanomaterials-based applications in cancer, stem cells, and environmental sciences. Yongho Seo received his B.S., M.S., and Ph.D. degrees in Materials Science and Engineering from Seoul National University in 1993, 1995, and 2000, respectively. In 2002, he joined the University of Virginia USA as a research associate. In 2004, he joined Northwestern University, USA as a postdoctoral fellow. In 2005, he joined the Samsung Advanced Institute of Technology as a research staff. In 2006, he joined Sejong University, Seoul, South Korea, as Assistant Professor. He is currently a Professor in the Department of Nanotechnology and Materials Engineering at Sejong University. His current research interests include 2D materials based nanodevice fabrication, smart windows, and energy harvesting materials.

coredata.dc:description: MXenes, the most recent addition to the 2D material family, have attracted significant attention owing to their distinctive characteristics, including high surface area, conductivity, surface characteristics, mechanical strength, etc. This review begins by presenting MXenes, providing insights into their structural characteristics, synthesis methods, and surface functional groups. The review covers a thorough analysis of MXene surface properties, including surface chemistry and termination group impacts. The properties of MXenes are influenced by their synthesis, which can be fluorine-based or fluorine-dependent. Fluorine-based synthesis techniques involve etching with fluorine-based reagents, mainly including HF or LiF/HCl, while fluorine-free methods include electrochemical etching, chemical vapor deposition (CVD), alkaline etching, Lewis acid-based etching, etc. These techniques result in the emergence of functional groups such as –F, –O, –OH, –Cl, etc. on the MXenes surface, depending on the synthesis method used. Properties of MXenes, such as electrical conductivity, electronic properties, catalytic activity, magnetic properties, mechanical strength, and chemical and thermal stability, are examined, and the role of functional groups in determining these properties is explored. The review delves into the diverse applications of MXenes, encompassing supercapacitors, battery materials, hydrogen storage, fuel cells, electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding, pollutant removal, water purification, flexible electronics, sensors, additive manufacturing, catalysis, biomedical and healthcare fields, etc. Finally, this article outlines the challenges and opportunities in the current and future development of MXenes research, addressing various aspects such as synthesis scalability, etching challenges, and multifunctionality, and exploring novel applications. The review concludes with future prospects and conclusions envisioning the impact of MXenes on future technologies and innovation.

coredata.dc:title: MXenes: Versatile 2D materials with tailored surface chemistry and diverse applications
